componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sean, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everybody to the Reynolds American Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Morris Moore, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the fourth quarter and full year as well as our 2016 outlook. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believes this provides
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the fourth quarter and full year as well as our 2016 outlook. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believes this provides additional perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release, which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com. Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO. The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we're not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. And also remind you that RAI's website is our primary source of publicly disclosed news and that we also use Twitter to disseminate company news. And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. I am absolutely delighted by our strong finish to what was already shaping up to be a remarkable year. RAI and all of our operating companies reported excellent results and integration of Newport continued to
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. I am absolutely delighted by our strong finish to what was already shaping up to be a remarkable year. RAI and all of our operating companies reported excellent results and integration of Newport continued to go very well. 2015 was truly a transformational year for RAI and its operating companies. And we have started the new year with significant momentum, especially in terms of returning value to our shareholders, a topic many of you are most interested in. 
Since the first of the year, we've taken 3 steps in particular that benefit our investors. First, as we announced this morning, we are increasing our dividend by 16.7%. Second, we successfully completed the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the United States for $5 billion in cash. And third, we recently announced the tender offer and redemption for the early repayment of some of the company's outstanding debt. As we said in the past, deleveraging is a priority for RAI and we're making good progress. And we're taking all these steps, while still investing in our core businesses as well as in innovations that are key to the success of our long-term growth and our transformation strategies. 
Before I discuss our core business performance, I'd like to give you an update on the innovations front. As you know, we recently created the RAI innovations company, which is focused on product development and commercialization of leading edge vapor and nicotine products. RAI innovations will drive speed to market with new products across the range of platform. In addition, the vapor collaboration that's now underway between R.J. Reynolds and British American Tobacco will facilitate the company's efforts to more efficiently meet the preferences of adult tobacco consumers in a rapidly evolving marketplace. And of course, one of the beneficiaries of that focus will be RJ Reynolds' vapor company's VUSE digital vapor cigarette. VUSE continue to perform very well in traditional retail channels, and its 4 additional styles that were introduced into September have been well received by adult tobacco consumers. The brand also introduced VUSE Connect, which is available online in the fourth quarter and VUSE also be available online starting next month. 
VUSE Port, a revolutionary liquid-based vapor tank system; and VUSE Pro, an innovative closed system will be introduced later this year. Adult tobacco consumers are looking for a vapor experience that delivers the performance and satisfaction of a tank with the simplicity of a light. Innovation backed by superior quality has helped make VUSE the vapor category leader, and we believe these new VUSE products will deliver what adult vapors want. 
In addition, our subsidiary remains focused on national distribution of Zonnic gum. Zonnic is now in more than 31,000 retail outlets, and the brand's expansion continues to go very well. 
Now let's discuss our operating company's performance, starting with cigarettes. Total domestic cigarette volumes for RAI's operating companies increased 33.6% in the fourth quarter, driven by the addition of the Newport brand to R.J. Reynolds portfolio. For the industry, overall cigarette volume declined just 5/10 of a percent for the quarter benefiting from lower gas prices and improved employment rates, both of which positively impacted adult tobacco consumers disposable income. When adjusted for wholesale inventory changes, industry shipments were down about 2/10 of a percent. Total cigarette market share for RAI's operating companies increased 3/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 33.8%, while their drive brands gained 6/10 of a percentage point to 31.3%. At RJ Reynolds, fourth quarter performance came in very strong and that was largely the result of Newport growth. 
As I mentioned earlier, the brand's integration continues to progress very well, and the company is on track to complete the manufacturing transition to the tobacco facility this year. Newport was added to R.J. Reynolds' retail contracts in mid-November following the exploration of the initial 5-month standstill period, and the brands expanded presence is delivering additional gains. As a result, R.J. Reynolds improved both adjusted operating income and margin substantially, as the company's mix to premium price brands grew to just over 70%. 
I'll remind you that R.J. Reynolds' retail market share is presented on a pro forma basis, which reflects share information from the company's new brand portfolio following the Lorillard acquisition and the related divestiture. Reflecting these factors, R.J. Reynolds total cigarette market share was in line with the prior year quarter at 31.8%. The company's expanded portfolio of drive brand, Newport, Camel and Pall Mall added 2/10 of a percentage point in combined market share to 29.3% for the quarter. And these 3 brands now make up about 92% of the company's total market share.
I'm very pleased to report that Newport's growth actually accelerated in the fourth quarter with the brand share of retail shipments increasing 6/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 13.6%, on volume growth of 4.8%. That's testament not just a Newport's expanded retail presence and the superior execution of the R.J. Reynolds trade marketing team, but also to the inherent equity of the brand. In addition, the company's consumer engagement on Newport is having a positive impact and that goes well for the brand in the year ahead. 
R.J. Reynolds' other 2 drive brand's, Camel and Pall Mall, continue to play key roles in the company's cigarette portfolio strategy and maintains steady performance in the fourth quarter. Camel's retail market share was in line with the prior year quarter at 8%. Pall Mall's market share was down 3/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter at 7.8%. While the brand has remained stable for the past 3 quarters, despite R.J. Reynolds seeing uptrading to premium price brands. R.J. Reynolds' consumer market team has exciting marketing plan for all the drive brands this year and these equity building initiatives are expected to further enhance performance. 
I'm pleased to say that both Santa Fe and American Snuff also delivered excellent financial and marketplace results in the fourth quarter, and it's not hard to see why. At Santa Fe, Natural American Spirit's distinctive super premium styles achieved a market share of 2%, which was up by 3/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter. Natural American Spirit's volume continue to make double-digit gain, increasing almost 18.5% for the quarter. At American Snuff, the flagship Grizzly brand continue to outperform the moist snuff industry. Grizzly increased fourth quarter market share by 9/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 30.8%, and that was on volume growth of 6.6% compared with the industry growth of about 2.5% for the quarter. 
All in all, I couldn't be more pleased with the performance of all of our operating companies. And I'm confident that they will continue their strong momentum and find additional opportunities for growth in 2016, allowing RAI to continue to return great value to our shareholders. These accomplishments do not happen by themselves, and I give the credit to our employees for their dedication and hard work. They're changing the game for both RAI and for the industry. And now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. On many measures, Reynolds American and its operating companies had another outstanding quarter and that brought our year to a very successful conclusion. As Susan said, our companies are making substantial pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. On many measures, Reynolds American and its operating companies had another outstanding quarter and that brought our year to a very successful conclusion. As Susan said, our companies are making substantial progress and as a result, the RAI board has approved an increase of 16.7% in our quarterly cash dividend to $0.42 per share or an annualized $1.68. This is consistent with our 75% target payout ratio. The dividend will be payable on April 1 to shareholders of record on March 10. 
RAI continues to deliver against its commitment to returning value to shareholders and will continue to look for additional opportunities to enhance that value over the long term. Now let's turn to our financial results. For the fourth quarter, RAI increased reported EPS by 35.7% from the prior year quarter to $0.19. On an adjusted basis, fourth quarter EPS was $0.48, up 9.1% from the prior year quarter. These results were supported by strong volumes across the board as well as higher pricing. Adjusted EPS excludes the following items. A charge of $0.11 per share for pension and postretirement mark-to-market adjustments, a charge of $0.01 per share for implementation cost primarily related to the sale of Natural American Spirit business outside the United States, a charge of $0.02 per share for tax items, a reduction of $0.17 per share related to the gain on divestiture, a benefit of $0.01 per share from the 2003 NPM adjustment claim and a one-time benefit of $0.01 per share for the New York NPM settlement. For the full year, RAI's reported EPS was $2.57 and that was up 87.6% from the prior year. 
Adjusted EPS for the full year was $1.98, up 15.8% from the prior year. Adjusted EPS excludes the items I've just mentioned as well as other items from earlier in the year, namely transaction related and financing costs, asset impairment and exit charges, and charges with Engle progeny cases and tobacco-related and other litigation. RAI's fourth quarter adjusted operating margin came in very strong again, increasing by 4.6 percentage points to 41.2%. 
Now I'll turn to our operating company's performance, where I'll discuss adjusted results were applicable. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results.
At R.J. Reynolds, fourth quarter performance was strong across the board. The company's reported operating income was $915 million. On an adjusted basis, fourth quarter operating income increased by 66.2% from the prior year quarter to $1.1 billion, benefiting from Newport's contribution as well as higher cigarette pricing with robust net price realization. For the full year, R.J. Reynolds' reported operating income was $3.4 billion. Full year adjusted operating income increased by just over 43% to $3.8 billion. You can really see R.J. Reynolds' improved performance in its adjusted operating margin, which grew by 4.1 percentage points to 44.6% in the fourth quarter, bringing the year's adjusted operating margin to 44.4%.
R.J. Reynolds' fourth quarter cigarette shipments were up 34.6% from the prior year quarter, driven by the addition of Newport. I would just note here that wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 6.9 billion units at the end of the quarter, up about 400 million from the prior year quarter. R.J. Reynolds' inventories of approximately 2.2 billion remained relatedly stable and reflect the normalized level of the new cigarette portfolio. 
Now moving on to Santa Fe, which also benefited from higher pricing and volume in the fourth quarter. Santa Fe's reported operating income was $112 million. On an adjusted basis, which excludes a one-time benefit of $1 million from the New York NPM settlement, the company's operating income came in at $111 million for the quarter, which was up 22.9%. For the full year, reported operating income was $449 million, while adjusted operating income increased 33.1% to $448 million. Santa Fe's fourth quarter adjusted operating margin gained 1.1 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 52.8%. 
For the year, adjusted operating margin came in at 54.8%. So I'm happy to report another strong performance by Santa Fe and its Natural American Spirit brand. 
Now let's turn to the strong showing in American Snuff. The company's fourth quarter reported operating income was $133 million, while adjusted operating income rose 18.4% to $134 million. Of course, these adjusted results benefited from higher volume and strong net pricing growth of almost 5%. Adjusted results exclude a $1 million charge for pension and postretirement mark-to-market adjustments, all of which added up to another strong year for American Snuff. Reported operating income rose to $502 million from the prior year, while adjusted operating income increased 13.9% to $503 million. American Snuff's fourth quarter adjusted operating margin jumped by 3.3 percentage points to 59.4%, and for the year, adjusted operating margin came to 58.8%. 
Before I turn to the Q&A, there're some other important items that I'd like to cover. As you know, we completed the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the U.S. in January for $5 billion. And we're moving quickly on our commitment to deleverage as efficiently as possible, while maintaining financial flexibility. To that end, we announced on February 4, a cash tender offer for up to $2.8 billion aggregate cash spend for certain outstanding notes and the redemption of $950 million aggregate principal amount of certain other outstanding notes. 
Final details of the tender and redemption will be announced upon completion. Given this progress, we would expect to reach the top end of our target leverage of 2.5x debt-to-EBITDA by the end of this year. RAI ended the year with total long-term debt of $16.9 billion. And as we've said before, we currently have a very manageable debt portfolio, which will be considerably reduced following the tender and redemption.
At the end of 2015, the company had cash balances of $2.6 billion, and in January, we contributed $325 million to the pension plans to further strengthen the plan's funded status. So based on the achievements in 2015 and our expectations for the year ahead, our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance range is $2.25 to $2.35, up 13.6% to 18.7% over last year's adjusted EPS of $1.98. 
Thank you all. Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

componenttext: So my first question how to deal with Newport and market share momentum that you're seeing there, clearly the expanded distribution and EDLP are helping, but can you pack it a little bit in terms of share trends by style, and what you guys are doing in terms of promotional -- promotion on some of the non-core SKUs?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivien. I mean, we were delighted with Newport progress in the fourth quarter. I mean, that was accelerated moment picking 0.6 share of market. We saw growth in both the premium menthol styles as well as in Newport read. And we also believe that con
componenttext: Sure, Vivien. I mean, we were delighted with Newport progress in the fourth quarter. I mean, that was accelerated moment picking 0.6 share of market. We saw growth in both the premium menthol styles as well as in Newport read. And we also believe that contributing to that in addition to the contracts obviously, the larger sales force is the consumer engagement strategies. We are out there talking to smokers and talking about the Newport brand in markets where they really -- it really hasn't been represented. So we will share a little more insight in the coming months of exactly what we're doing with various styles, but we see upside potential in certainly both the menthol and the non-menthol.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's terrific. Thank you. And then on NAS, now that you guys have crossed the 2 share, which is so impressive. How you guys thinking about managing your price on that brand to maintain the momentum in the profitability that you're seeing there?
componenttext: That's terrific. Thank you. And then on NAS, now that you guys have crossed the 2 share, which is so impressive. How you guys thinking about managing your price on that brand to maintain the momentum in the profitability that you're seeing there?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: NAS has been priced at what we call that so superpremium price point with certainly a gap to the mainstream premium brand. And we have sustained that price gap, certainly, for the last 10 years. So I would expect that you will see us continue to maintain
componenttext: NAS has been priced at what we call that so superpremium price point with certainly a gap to the mainstream premium brand. And we have sustained that price gap, certainly, for the last 10 years. So I would expect that you will see us continue to maintain that price gap. As you know, we added resources to the sales force last year for Natural American Spirit, and certainly, that has contributed, and the brand has natural momentum. The values that brand carries are attracted -- are attractive to adult smokers across the country.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first on guidance for 2016 entrance. So obviously, we were lapping the acquisitions a little bit difficult, just in terms of what you're expecting for underlying trends. So what is embedded in your guidance in terms of industry volume outlook? How much
componenttext: So first on guidance for 2016 entrance. So obviously, we were lapping the acquisitions a little bit difficult, just in terms of what you're expecting for underlying trends. So what is embedded in your guidance in terms of industry volume outlook? How much cost synergies are essentially expecting for the full year? And then, in terms of some of the investments around VUSE and some of the eBay per products what is embedded in that guidance?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, let me start with the industry. In the industry next year, we are expecting that 2% to 3% decline, that's in line with our historic VUSE. Obviously, I think the macroeconomic factors are pointing into the consumer's favor this year as it did in
componenttext: Sure. Yes, let me start with the industry. In the industry next year, we are expecting that 2% to 3% decline, that's in line with our historic VUSE. Obviously, I think the macroeconomic factors are pointing into the consumer's favor this year as it did in 2015. We are expecting 2% to 3% decline for next year. With regard to the synergies, the $800 million in synergies that we've talked about continues to be our expectation. We've not identified anything meaningful, positive or negative, that would have us come off of that number at this time. So we certainly are, I would say, a bit ahead of schedule in terms of achieving the synergies. And we hope to achieve those as quickly as we can. As you know, we've incentivized our organization to do that as quickly as possible. But the 800 continues to be the number, and it is our hope that we can accelerate that throughout the year. The last question you had was one VUSE and, I guess, the investment that we have on vapor. And I'm not sure I have any specifics on that. I think, we continue to make great progress, certainly, the consolidation in the manufacturing facilities that we had in the back half of 2015 was a real positive. It put us on a very good position from a cost basis. We continue to make progress on our cost structure and certain profitability objectives that we have going forward. But a lot of it will depend on how do the innovations -- how are they receive by the consumers and how quickly do we look to expand that or not. So at this point, that's probably all I can say on that.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. If I could just follow up on the industry volume outlook, so understanding that this is in line with, maybe, the medium-term target, but I guess, year-to-date, it's still tracking maybe below that in terms of some of the major channe
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. If I could just follow up on the industry volume outlook, so understanding that this is in line with, maybe, the medium-term target, but I guess, year-to-date, it's still tracking maybe below that in terms of some of the major channel data that we're seeing and kind of hearing anecdotally. So are you guys seeing anything that would sort of cause you to think that we do revert back to kind of the more normalized rate of decline for this year? And do you expect, maybe, some tax driven retail price increases to be a bit of headwind as we think about 2016 volumes?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we looked at the volume. And to your point, we don't see any big changes coming into the year. The macroeconomics in terms of what affects adult tobacco consumer's disposable income are the same as they were last year. We did see declines in the
componenttext: I think, we looked at the volume. And to your point, we don't see any big changes coming into the year. The macroeconomics in terms of what affects adult tobacco consumer's disposable income are the same as they were last year. We did see declines in the fourth quarter of 0.5. So while -- and of course, that was a quarter you remember that we lapped the buyout. So there were dynamics there. I think, our view on the volume in the long term, we've seen 2% to 4% declines in this sector on combustible. And we are taking the view this year that it will be on a low end of that range. So remodel that 2% to 3% range. Obviously, it would be nice to be wrong. But I think that taking that view consistent with history is may be conservative, but it's the right way to model at this stage in the year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the pricing environment in cigarettes. Specifically, if you've seen any changes kind of after the retail contracts you are able to be reset later last year and then into the first quarter? And how you'r
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the pricing environment in cigarettes. Specifically, if you've seen any changes kind of after the retail contracts you are able to be reset later last year and then into the first quarter? And how you're feeling about cigarette pricing?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we certainly saw a net price realization. As we discussed, we feel good about the environment. There we, obviously, list prices taken in December. And I think, as the contracts has been reset, and you guys certainly have some transparency t
componenttext: Well, I think, we certainly saw a net price realization. As we discussed, we feel good about the environment. There we, obviously, list prices taken in December. And I think, as the contracts has been reset, and you guys certainly have some transparency to those retail contract. Of course, we do have a higher proportion of our contracts in EDLP that does affect pricing. Imperial tobacco has extended their contract universe. So we will see how this plays out in the third quarter. But I wouldn't describe it as ramping up promotional spend. We don't see that. We continue to see relative stability once those discount rates were announced following that contract change. And we're still in the process of resetting those contracts. We've done very well in terms of the resetting all of the independence. Many of the chains have certain times of year when their change their plan So we expect to have everything converted by late March, early April. And we're very pleased with the results of that selling.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just add that it continued to be a very competitive marketplace and that's something that we experienced all through 2015. And we continue to monitor the market place and adjust accordingly based on the environment, but really no changes fro
componenttext: Well, I would just add that it continued to be a very competitive marketplace and that's something that we experienced all through 2015. And we continue to monitor the market place and adjust accordingly based on the environment, but really no changes from our perspective.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then I just follow up one last question. In the past, you've talked about maybe revisiting the dividend payout ratio, maybe contingent upon your debt paydown. You talked about getting to the higher end of your target range by the end of the y
componenttext: Perfect. And then I just follow up one last question. In the past, you've talked about maybe revisiting the dividend payout ratio, maybe contingent upon your debt paydown. You talked about getting to the higher end of your target range by the end of the year. Can you just remind us what kind of factors you would be looking at with your leverage and when it would be time to kind of revisit that dividend payout?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, that's pretty straightforward. We do expect to reach the high end of our range on the back half of this year based on the tender and redemption that we've announced in the past. With that what we have said historically is that we would not r
componenttext: Yes, I think, that's pretty straightforward. We do expect to reach the high end of our range on the back half of this year based on the tender and redemption that we've announced in the past. With that what we have said historically is that we would not revisit a dividend payout ratio change or a share repurchase until we achieve that deleveraging. So I would expect once we reach our range, we'll have discussions with our board and we will move forward from there.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about the Newport share gains, and do you have any visibility on where that sourcing share from?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the Newport share gains, and do you have any visibility on where that sourcing share from?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Michael as we said in the fourth quarter, that accelerated market share growth of Newport is really widespread. And we saw it both in premium menthol and we saw it in the non-menthol, particularly the red style. So I would -- we are crediting tha
componenttext: I think, Michael as we said in the fourth quarter, that accelerated market share growth of Newport is really widespread. And we saw it both in premium menthol and we saw it in the non-menthol, particularly the red style. So I would -- we are crediting that to a couple of things. One, the significantly larger sales force. Reynolds took that brand over in July, August. Number two, we started to have our contracts starting to set up from the middle of November, and the first contract to be converted were the menthol-only contracts, which were previously the strongest Newport outlook. So we have continued to -- we have seen that acceleration. And certainly, if you compare it historically to Newport's growth, Newport historically got all its growth in market share somehow in the first quarter and then held on. So we -- and this is, of course, the first year we've owned it. We've only owned it for 2 quarters. So we've seen that acceleration, and we believe we have good programs in place to continue that. But we'll certainly provide more information on that as the year unfolds. It's just early. Thanks.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: It really comes from a mix across the board. I mean, if you look at our nondrive brands. I guess, there's about 2.5 share points of nondrive brands left. As you know, 92% of our volume is in the drive brand, but certainly, it would source from those. Certainly, it would source from some of all 3 of nondrive brands and from ITG's nondrive brand. It really has a broad-based appeal to adult smoker.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

Susan, you made a comment that you expect new format of VUSE to generate even more interest with consumers this year, but I guess, I'm curious how you're going to bring consumer back to the category that may have leftover issues in general with product performance and/or maybe concerns about the relative safety of the products. How are you going to community to these consumers to come back to category and try these products again, especially VUSE?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, what's interesting is our consumer data continues to show growth in trial, while the category overall is flat. So I think that the consumers continue to desire to find satisfaction in noncombustible products. And I believe that our new VUSE innova
componenttext: I mean, what's interesting is our consumer data continues to show growth in trial, while the category overall is flat. So I think that the consumers continue to desire to find satisfaction in noncombustible products. And I believe that our new VUSE innovation, which are certainly aimed at delivering against the crux of their issue, which is improving the satisfaction without messing around with tanks and open liquids, et cetera. And so we will be, obviously, primarily in the traditional channels, but that is where people buy their tobacco products, and we will certainly use marketing materials to talk about the differences in these new innovations versus cigalikes and encourage trial. Obviously, whenever you launch a new product, encouraging trial will be part of that marketing plan. And we'll keep you posted, because of course, we will be in lead market situations with these products and we'll be able to report how that's received. And as Andrew said earlier, determining the timing and the right opportunity to expand that is something that we'll read a long way, but we're enthusiastic that we've gone a long to meet what is really the consumers which is more satisfaction in a product that could reduce the harm that's caused by combustible.

componenttext: Sure, Owen. I'll take the Camel question, and appreciate it. You will remember in the fourth quarter that we had to take a couple of styles of Camel off the market. And so you will see reflected in those shipments to retail. If you will, that was a double lammy, because when you take shipments back from retail, was negative. So we are confident, we are seeing a good path with Camel and we do believe we will continue to grow market share. And it is fair to say that the organization has been focused on the contact universe, of course, and Newport is certainly now the flagship of the portfolio. But as these contracts bid in across the country, opportunities for Camel outside of its strong suite, which was the West Coast, we continue to be encouraging. And I think, we will be pleased with what we see from Camel this year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, as far as the debt, when we will start to see the benefits on the reduced interest. Assuming we complete all of this, it's whenever we settle. So I would say in the near term assuming we complete the tender and redemption that's when the bene
componenttext: I would say, as far as the debt, when we will start to see the benefits on the reduced interest. Assuming we complete all of this, it's whenever we settle. So I would say in the near term assuming we complete the tender and redemption that's when the benefits will start to accrue. As far as the rate going forward, I really can't comment on that. I think, we have to wait until after the tender and redemption are completed. And we'll have a better sense of exactly where that nets out and exactly what the rate is going forward. And really, the only other piece that I would add is just keep in mind, we will be seeing some interest reduction. But keep in mind that we're also will be seeing the reduction of some of our operating income coming through on our international business as well. So there is a bit of an offset this year, but certainly, we expect the interest to be a real positive for us going forward.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think, remember in '15, of course, we were  supporting Winston in sale of to a lesser extent for the Lorillard transaction and that divestiture to Imperial tobacco. So that's one way to think about Pall Mall. That is that time when Pall Mall lost
componenttext: Well, I think, remember in '15, of course, we were  supporting Winston in sale of to a lesser extent for the Lorillard transaction and that divestiture to Imperial tobacco. So that's one way to think about Pall Mall. That is that time when Pall Mall lost 3/10 of a share point. In fact, it has been dead flat for the following 3 quarters. So I think, as again this universal resets, we will see how consumers respond to the very competitive offers that are out there with ourselves and ITG and Atrea. As we have seen in past years, the brands that are not supported by a company, are at risk or are usually stepped into drive brands of somebody. And -- So we have a couple of share points that are in that bucket and so do both of our competitors. So I think, we will see in this first half how the marketing offers in the brand propositions are playing to look at what is going to happen to those brands that are not drive brands in anybody's portfolio.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
