componenttext: Next question is from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just on industry volume trends, Susan. Just obviously trends have come in better even as we're lapping some of the positive tailwinds. So do you think that may be down 2% that you were expecting at the beginning of the year, is now certainly potent
componenttext: First, just on industry volume trends, Susan. Just obviously trends have come in better even as we're lapping some of the positive tailwinds. So do you think that may be down 2% that you were expecting at the beginning of the year, is now certainly potential for upside to that number? And then, is there any sort of data that gives you more clarity in terms of where recent drivers, it's a frequency penetration, because it seems like even as we're lapping kind of the consumers having more money from lower gas prices, all of that is abating to some extent, and we're still seeing pretty healthy industry volume trend.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Judy, I would say that the macro -- the macros like the lower gas prices, they raises the minimum wage. These are positively impacting the disposable income of the tobacco consumer. And you continue to see people sort of trading up. And when you so t
componenttext: Yes, Judy, I would say that the macro -- the macros like the lower gas prices, they raises the minimum wage. These are positively impacting the disposable income of the tobacco consumer. And you continue to see people sort of trading up. And when you so these combustible volumes, you understand that there are some categories, bags of tobacco and these sort of things where people -- there are not more people are consuming cigarettes. So that's not the driver there. But people are trading up to premium, and in some context, that means trading up to combustible. So we feel good about those macros. To your point, we modeled certainly our guidance on a 2% to 3% industry decline. The first quarter was flat on an adjusted basis. As we get into the half, certainly, we are already thinking that that's going to be certainly to the lower end of our anticipated decline. But we will reevaluate that once we get through the half.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Andrew, I wanted to understand a little bit more specifically, if the margin improvement that we saw on the RJRT side, and certainly, the cost synergies played a role and pricing has been positive. But you also talked about some of the othe
componenttext: Okay. And then Andrew, I wanted to understand a little bit more specifically, if the margin improvement that we saw on the RJRT side, and certainly, the cost synergies played a role and pricing has been positive. But you also talked about some of the other internal efforts that potentially drove some of that margin improvement, and seems like sequentially, we also saw the improvement there too. So can you just, maybe, quantify some of these big buckets of cost savings and to the extent that you can identify where savings have hit between cost and SG&A, because it seems like most of that really hit cost, and I would have thought from a cost synergy perspective it's more SG&A initially and then moving to cost as we get into manufacturing integration completed?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, to your point, obviously, the Newport acquisition played a major role and that we are seeing the synergies come through, the cost synergies are playing out as we anticipated. So you're seeing benefits from that. The net price realization we
componenttext: Yes, I think, to your point, obviously, the Newport acquisition played a major role and that we are seeing the synergies come through, the cost synergies are playing out as we anticipated. So you're seeing benefits from that. The net price realization we talk about 14%, about half of that was mix, about half of that was actually pricing. So we've seen very robust pricing coming through on the margins. And really on the internal side, we continue to drive efficiencies throughout our business. So some of that is coming through in our manufacturing environment. We have a number of different initiatives that are aimed at optimizing our processes and operations as well as our supply chain. But we also have a number of other information technology-type initiatives that are aimed at optimizing some of our spend internally here. So all of that is pointing out, I think, over time. And I think it continues to be a very strong story for us in terms of our operating margins, not just pricing, it's actually coming through more efficient operations as well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes. That's -- we continue to see sales growth in both vapor and Niconovum, but obviously, it is reflective of not having our international business within that segment.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mike Lavery with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from Mike Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just elaborate a little bit on the significant strength in Natural American Spirit. And specifically, a couple of things, one is, did it get any extra space from research? And especially if it didn't, then what are some of the drivers there just
componenttext: Could you just elaborate a little bit on the significant strength in Natural American Spirit. And specifically, a couple of things, one is, did it get any extra space from research? And especially if it didn't, then what are some of the drivers there just given the particularly strong comp in this quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, we continue to be very pleased with Natural American Spirit. And we are seeing, most of this growth is actually same-store sales growth, because much of that distribution expansion had occurred as we lapped this quarter. We are also pleased with
componenttext: Michael, we continue to be very pleased with Natural American Spirit. And we are seeing, most of this growth is actually same-store sales growth, because much of that distribution expansion had occurred as we lapped this quarter. We are also pleased with the space that Natural American Spirit did retain in the context of this new round of contract, and this is really the consumer trading up to premium. And Natural American Spirit, of course, has a very distinctive positioning. It's a distinctive product. And it hit that 2 share point mark. And as we've talked before, it's not really 2 share points anywhere. It has strong popularity in many of the -- in many cities around the country. And it's continuing to grow in just about every state. So I think it's just -- it's course -- it's on course.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just given like you said the disparity in market shares, are you seeing geographic expansion momentum. I mean, obviously, called out the same-store sales, but is that giving any sort of indirect effect of just better momentum to move into new territor
componenttext: And just given like you said the disparity in market shares, are you seeing geographic expansion momentum. I mean, obviously, called out the same-store sales, but is that giving any sort of indirect effect of just better momentum to move into new territories or to develop in places where it's underpenetrated?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has very broad distribution today. I would say that there is not so much more to go in terms of storefront. What we do see is opportunity to increase the number of styles in the stores where we have the distribution. And of course, as the core styles p
componenttext: It has very broad distribution today. I would say that there is not so much more to go in terms of storefront. What we do see is opportunity to increase the number of styles in the stores where we have the distribution. And of course, as the core styles pick up, it enables us to add style into that range. But I think, it's on track and the growth year-over-year is tremendous, and of course, there is also sequential growth. But Natural American Spirit has been -- it had this momentum now for probably at least 10 quarters. And I don't see it's really down.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I would just add that the growth that we're seeing is broad-based. It's across the entire U.S. It's in areas where it is overdeveloped. It's in the areas where it's under development. It's really across all of various states, east and west. So we
componenttext: Michael, I would just add that the growth that we're seeing is broad-based. It's across the entire U.S. It's in areas where it is overdeveloped. It's in the areas where it's under development. It's really across all of various states, east and west. So we're very pleased with that, but there's nothing really unique about this quarter versus some of the past quarters.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just on the margins for Santa Fe too, the comp obviously was very tough and you still put up a nice big boost. Is that, primarily, I know you had the good pricing, but is operating margin a big piece of that? Or what's kind
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just on the margins for Santa Fe too, the comp obviously was very tough and you still put up a nice big boost. Is that, primarily, I know you had the good pricing, but is operating margin a big piece of that? Or what's kind of the trajectory for the year in terms of what some of the drivers, and what I think you're looking at?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think for Santa Fe, it's pretty straightforward. It really is pricing, and we obviously don't discount that brand. So pricing is a significant component. And then obviously, we continue to get efficiencies because of the higher volume in the larger
componenttext: Yes, I think for Santa Fe, it's pretty straightforward. It really is pricing, and we obviously don't discount that brand. So pricing is a significant component. And then obviously, we continue to get efficiencies because of the higher volume in the larger scale. So all of that is playing into seeing operating margins continue to grow.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: I think, as we said this out, we laid out our priorities really being our balance sheet metrics. And I think, we've been very sort of methodical and trying to address those balance sheet metrics. We first hit our pension. As you know, in January, we had $325 million to increase the fund of status there. This most recent tender and redemption was a big play for us, and certainly, got our leverage down into a range. The $500 million, we do anticipate paying off at this point. We reviewed that over the past few months and feel like we're in a good position to move forward with that. And I think as we get into that range, we certainly will be looking at our dividend policy and we will be looking at other ways to return capital to shareholders in the form of share repurchases and other opportunities. So nothing really has changed on that front. I think, we're trying to be very methodical in sort of addressing all of these priorities. It's never been a question of 1 versus the other. It's a matter of how do we sequence this, and how we get to a position where we feel good about sort of a long-term plan. Though that -- I think that still is considered our position. And then I think we're in a great spot heading into the back half of the year.

componenttext: I would say, we're pretty well through that myself. We have seen over the last 9 months retailers reducing their volumes on e-cigarettes, VUSE, of course, is #1 by 3x. But I think a lot of that inventory reduction has come out, and of course, then it depends on the individual retailers, how they are working with their inventory. Certainly, nobody wants to be out of stock, but it's also a heavy carrying cost. So that's something that is always has to be balanced. But certainly, the diversion from combustible to e-cigarette is long past.

componenttext: Okay. Thank you for your participation today. Before we sign off, I'd like to update on one other matter. We will be meeting many of you in New York and London in the coming weeks, and I know you will join me in wishing Moore the very best and then welcoming Bob to his new role. componenttext: Good morning. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Reynolds American First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the first quarter as well as our outlook for the rest of the year. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believes this pro
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the first quarter as well as our outlook for the rest of the year. As usual, our discussion will include adjusted results as management believes this provides additional perspective on our underlying business performance. A reconciliation of reported to adjusted earnings is in our press release which is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com.
Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; and Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO. The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. I'd also remind you that RAI's website is our primary source of publicly disclosed news and that we also use Twitter to disseminate company news. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As we've said previously, our operating companies entered the new year with strong momentum and that helped to drive an exceptional first quarter for RAI. All of our operating companies continued to deliver a
componenttext:
Thank you, Morris, and good morning, everyone. As we've said previously, our operating companies entered the new year with strong momentum and that helped to drive an exceptional first quarter for RAI. All of our operating companies continued to deliver against their strategies turning in another excellent performance. Significant positive factors in the quarter were the addition of Newport, higher cigarette and moist snuff volume combined with high pricing and the gain on the divestiture of Natural American Spirit's business outside the United States. 
I am especially pleased with the smooth sailing on the integration of Newport. And this success underscores the transformational nature of our acquisition in June last year. Newport has made really impressive gains in market share since then, and it's been a driving force behind the accelerated business performance you see today. And now another milestone is within sight, we expect Newport's manufacturing integration to be completed by about the middle of this year, well ahead of the 18-month transition that we initially projected. In addition, Newport is now far more visible as retailers across the country, as the reset of retail merchandisers is almost complete and our company's trade and consumer marketing engagement has ramped up very well. 
As you can imagine, this kind of transition has a lot of moving parts. Our employees have made it look easy, but I can assure you it's been quite an achievement. And they've done it while keeping the rest of the business firmly on track. Clearly, Newport has brought a new vitality to the business in what continues to be a competitive and dynamic environment. So in light of our strong performance out of the gate for the year, I'm pleased to report that RAI remains on track for earnings growth of 13.6% to 18.7% for the year. So that's how we're returning excellent value to our shareholders. 
And now I'd like to briefly recap some other highlights from the quarter. RAI successfully completed the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the U.S. and followed that with an early repayment of a portion of the company's outstanding debt. We also increased our quarterly cash dividend by more than 16% and created a new subsidiary called RAI Innovations Company to drive speed-to-market of leading-edge products. 
Innovation is a key part of our strategy to transform the tobacco industry and it's a core competitive strength for our company, especially at R.J. Reynolds Vapor. Its VUSE digital vapor cigarette continues to make headway in the first quarter and the brand remains the leader in traditional tobacco channels. In fact, VUSE is about 3x the size of its nearest competitor in those channels, and the brand just been ranked at the top of 2015 most successful new products in convenience stores. VUSE is now available in almost 115,000 stores. In recent months the brand rolled out 2 more formats online, VUSE Connect and VUSE Fob, and work continues on the development of the Port and Pro format. We will keep you posted on the timing of those innovations in the months ahead. 
At Niconovum USA, progress continues to be made with the national expansion of the Zonnic nicotine replacement therapy gum. Zonnic is now in about 33,000 stores and is targeting further expansion this year. The brand has just introduced 4 styles in a 40-count package at 2 retail store chains and plans to roll out a 10-count mini lozenge in the summer. 
Moving on to our operating company's performance, I would first just note a change in the retail market share reporting. RAI's operating companies, cigarette and moist snuff shipments to retail market shares have been revised to reflect the new universe of direct customers following the Lorillard acquisition. This revision results in slightly higher absolute share levels in 2015 on some of our operating companies' brand, but does not affect overall share trend. Prior year market share data has been restated on this basis for comparison purposes. 
Now let's start with combustibles. Total first quarter cigarette volumes for RAI's operating companies increased 34.2% from the prior year quarter, a comparison that reflects Newport's contribution. Improved economic factors such as lower gas prices continued to benefit the disposable income of adult tobacco consumers in the quarter, and that drove industry cigarette volume higher by 4/10 of a percent. When adjusted for wholesale inventory changes, industry shipments were relatively flat. Total cigarette market share for RAI's operating companies increased 3/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter to 34.6%, with their drive brands adding half a percentage point to 32%. These brands now make up about 93% of our operating company's total cigarette market share. 
Of course, the growth in Newport helps fuel the strong first quarter at R.J. Reynolds in addition to higher volumes and pricing. R.J. Reynolds' total cigarette market share was in line with the prior year quarter at 32.5%. The company's expanded portfolio of drive brand, Newport, Camel and Pall Mall, added 2/10 of a percentage point in combined market share bringing that to 30% for the quarter. Newport, the nation's #1 menthol brand continued to show excellent momentum, increasing share of retail shipments by another 6/10 of percentage point from the prior year quarter to 14%, and that was on volume growth of 3.4%. 
Increased distribution, merchandising and product visibility is having a positive impact on the brand, as is the increased engagement with adult tobacco consumers. Newport launched a Payday Everyday integrated national campaign in March, and that's adding some excitement to the brand. And for the first time in many years for Newport, brand ambassadors are now engaging with franchise and competitive adult tobacco consumers across the nation. Equity building initiatives also continue on R.J. Reynolds' other 2 drive brand, Camel and Pall Mall, which continue to play their key roles in the company's cigarette portfolio strategy. 
In the first quarter, Camel's retail cigarette market share was down 2/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter at 8.2%. I would note that Camel had an especially strong first quarter last year. And even with this tough comparison, the brand is performing well and with up a 10th of a share point on a sequential basis. 
Pall Mall's first quarter retail market share was down 3/10 of a percentage point versus prior year at 7.8%, as we continue to see consumers move up to premium brands. But the brand has remained relatively stable since the second quarter of last year and it remains the nation's largest value brand. 
I'm pleased to say that both Santa Fe and American Snuff knock the ball out of the park this quarter, both financially and in the marketplace. At Santa Fe, Natural American Spirit's distinctive super premium style achieved a market share of 2%, which was up by 3/10 of a percentage point from the prior year quarter. Natural American Spirit's volume continue to make double-digit gains, increasing by just over 22% in the quarter. 
And at American Snuff, their flagship Grizzly brand delivered first quarter retail market share of 30.8%, up 4/10 of a percentage point. Grizzly is advancing its leadership position in the growing pouch style, and recent promotions have focused on the brand's differentiation and superior quality to increase awareness in trial. For American Snuff overall, first quarter moist snuff market share was 33.4%, that was on volume growth of 3.3% compared to moist snuff industry growth of about 5%. I would point out that industry growth was up on the national expansion of competitive line extensions. 
So that's a wrap up of very successful first quarter. RAI and our operating companies are off to a great start this year, Newport's integration is ahead of schedule and we're well positioned for solid growth in the months ahead. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. As far as financial performance goes, Reynolds American and its operating companies had an impressive quarter and we continue to return substantial value to our shareholders. RAI increased reported EPS by abou
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan, and good morning, everyone. As far as financial performance goes, Reynolds American and its operating companies had an impressive quarter and we continue to return substantial value to our shareholders. RAI increased reported EPS by about 592% from the prior year quarter to $2.49. This was driven primarily by the gain on the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the United States. 
On an adjusted basis, first quarter EPS was $0.50, up 16.3% from the prior year quarter benefiting from higher volumes and pricing across the board. Adjusted EPS excludes the following items: A gain of $2.11 for the divestiture of Natural American Spirit's business outside the U.S., a charge of $0.11 per share for debt in financing cost and a charge of $0.01 per share primarily related to the implementation cost following the Lorillard acquisition and the sale of Natural American Spirit's business overseas. 
RAI's first quarter adjusted operating margin was outstanding, increasing by 8 percentage points to more than 45%. To add some perspective on the impact of the Lorillard acquisition and other recent efficiency initiatives that we've driven internally, I'd point out that our adjusted operating margin has increased by more than 10 percentage points since this time 2 years ago. 
Now let's turn to our operating company's performance where I'll discuss adjusted results where applicable. Please refer to the schedules at the end of our earnings release for reconciliations from our GAAP to adjusted results. As Susan said, R.J. Reynolds' continued its impressive run in the quarter, increasing reported operating income by more than 88% to about $1.1 billion. The company benefited significantly from Newport's contribution as well as robust net price realization. 
On an adjusted basis, the company's first quarter operating income increased by 73.8% from the prior year quarter to $1.1 billion. This excludes charges of $13 million for Engle progeny lawsuits and $1 million for implementation costs. Once again, R.J. Reynolds improved performance in its adjusted operating margin, which jumped by 6.4 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 46.5% as R.J. Reynolds' mix of premium cigarettes increased significantly. A strong positive factor behind these results was R.J. Reynolds' first quarter cigarette shipments, which increased by just over 35% from the prior year quarter driven by the addition of Newport. 
I would just note here that wholesale inventory levels for the industry were approximately 7.2 billion units at the end of the quarter, up about 700 million from the prior year quarter. R.J. Reynolds' inventories of approximately 2.2 billion remained relatively stable sequentially and continue to reflect the normalized level of new cigarette portfolio. 
Now moving on to Santa Fe, which also continue to benefit from higher pricing and volume on its super premium brand, Natural American Spirit. Santa Fe accelerated its first quarter operating income by 33.2% to $123 million, and that translated into a substantial gain in the company's operating margin which grew by 2.5 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 56.4%. 
I'm pleased to report that American Snuff also powered ahead. The company's first quarter operating income of $133 million reflected an increase of almost 12% from the prior year quarter. And for the first time, American Snuff's operating margin passed the 60% mark coming in at 61.3%, which was up nearly 2.5 percentage points from the prior year quarter. 
Before I turn to the Q&A, I'd like to cover some other important events that occurred in the quarter that demonstrate our commitment to returning value to our shareholders. We increased our quarterly cash dividend by 16.7% and completed the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the U.S. for approximately $5 billion. And we also moved quickly to deleverage as we promised. After completing the cash tender offer and redemption of about $3.6 billion, RAI's long-term debt at the end of the quarter stood at $13.2 billion. It carries an average interest rate of 4.9% and an average maturity of 12.6 years. The reduction in interest expense as a result of the reduced level of debt will more than offset the loss of the operating income related to the sale of Natural American Spirit's business outside the U.S. And as I've said before, we expect to reach the top end of our target leverage up 2.5x debt-to-EBITDA in the back half of this year. 
We remain on track to achieve approximately $800 million in cost synergies as we previously announced. Susan mentioned that we're ahead of schedule on the manufacturing integration, and this has been factored in to our earnings guidance. I would also note that at the end of first quarter, the company had a cash balance of $4.4 billion. On April 15, R.J. Reynolds made its MSA payment of $2.3 billion, which included $597 million paid into the NPM disputed payments account. Finally, I'd remind you that we contributed $325 million to the pension plans in January, further strengthening the plan's funded status. 
So those are the highlights of what was an exceptional quarter for RAI and our operating companies. Based on this success, our expectations for the rest of the year were reaffirming our adjusted EPS guidance range of $2.25 to $2.35, which is up 13.6% to 18.7% over last year's adjusted EPS. This adjusted EPS guidance excludes the items that I mentioned earlier. 
Thank you all. Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

componenttext: I just actually want to build on a couple of those points you made at the end there, Andrew. So first, it's great to hear that the Newport integration is ahead of schedule. I'm curious if you could kind of outline how this played into the guidance decision to not change the range or the synergy capture. Sounds like you didn't tweak the timing or the amount of synergy capture even though you've kind of pulled out forward. I'm just wondering if you could walk us through that decision.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The synergy capture, we're still -- maybe just to back up a bit, we're still tracking to the $800 million. That is still the number that we're looking at. We haven't identified anything positive or negative to have us come off that number. We have ac
componenttext: Yes. The synergy capture, we're still -- maybe just to back up a bit, we're still tracking to the $800 million. That is still the number that we're looking at. We haven't identified anything positive or negative to have us come off that number. We have accelerated the time frame in terms of that capture. So with the integration of Newport coming into our factory at midyear, we are moving that up somewhat and that certainly is contemplated in our earnings guidance today. So we continue to be very pleased with how that integration is moving ahead, and we're going to continue to watch that and see how that plays out for the back half of the year.

I'm curious if I'm missing anything there on the timing and if those changes are -- or how do you think about this in the context of your capital return plan going forward?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bill, I think, obviously, we're looking at it on a run rate basis. So our calculations have a somewhat higher than the top end of that range. Certainly, when you include postretirement obligations, that takes us well above that range. Having said tha
componenttext: Yes. Bill, I think, obviously, we're looking at it on a run rate basis. So our calculations have a somewhat higher than the top end of that range. Certainly, when you include postretirement obligations, that takes us well above that range. Having said that, we do anticipate paying off the maturity that comes in August. It's $500 million of debt that we will -- we anticipate paying off at that point in time. And with the business continuing to grow at the pace that we're looking at, back half of the year is still our target.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Vivien Azer with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Vivien Azer with Cowen & Company.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on Newport, clearly, another good quarter in terms of market share momentum. I was wondering whether you could dive in a little bit on any tweaks that you're making around pricing or promotion around the various styles within the Newport brand family,
componenttext: So on Newport, clearly, another good quarter in terms of market share momentum. I was wondering whether you could dive in a little bit on any tweaks that you're making around pricing or promotion around the various styles within the Newport brand family, please.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's talk a little bit about this quarter 1 promotion environment. Obviously, we are very pleased with Newport up to 14 share points, that 6/10 versus a year ago. There's also sequential growth, obviously. But if you look at the quarter from our sp
componenttext: Sure. Let's talk a little bit about this quarter 1 promotion environment. Obviously, we are very pleased with Newport up to 14 share points, that 6/10 versus a year ago. There's also sequential growth, obviously. But if you look at the quarter from our spend perspective, we actually spent less marketing dollars or promotional dollars on Newport in the first quarter of this year than we spent on it in the first quarter of last year. And that -- the same goes for Camel and Pall Mall in our context, we spent less resources and the competitive promotional environment was different. This has to do with timing, but the -- as you see in the margin growth, we had an exceptional growth in those margins and we're pleased with those market shares, particularly in the context of that promotional timing and absolute spend. In terms of Newport specifically, we saw growth on both the menthol, which is -- the prominent growth is on menthol. The premium -- and you saw that in our premium mix, but we've also seen growth on the non-menthol. So we will provide some more information on those brands and styles and equity programs as we get into this year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then on Natural American Spirit, the price mix realization was very robust, the best we've seen in almost 2 years and far better than we saw in the first -- in 2015, excuse me. So I was wondering whether there are any callouts there because I
componenttext: Perfect. And then on Natural American Spirit, the price mix realization was very robust, the best we've seen in almost 2 years and far better than we saw in the first -- in 2015, excuse me. So I was wondering whether there are any callouts there because I'm looking at over 5 points of price realization, which is really robust given the price points.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Vivien, we're certainly -- as we look at that, we were a little bit lower than that. We were closer to 4.4%, but it certainly was a very good quarter. I think a lot of that comes down to strong volume and we really did not expand, to Susan's point, w
componenttext: Yes. Vivien, we're certainly -- as we look at that, we were a little bit lower than that. We were closer to 4.4%, but it certainly was a very good quarter. I think a lot of that comes down to strong volume and we really did not expand, to Susan's point, we did not expand some of the marketing dollars and some of the direct mail dollars that were going out the door at the rate that we increased for volumes. So 4.4% is a very good number for us and I think that's -- that certainly is a good review for the rest of the year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Russ Miller, on for Nik. I just wanted to ask on the all other segment. The losses there still seem pretty sizable. Could you provide some perspective on what's specifically is driving that? Where we are in the vapor reinvestment cycle? And when w
componenttext: This is Russ Miller, on for Nik. I just wanted to ask on the all other segment. The losses there still seem pretty sizable. Could you provide some perspective on what's specifically is driving that? Where we are in the vapor reinvestment cycle? And when we can expect losses in that segment to moderate?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, if you look at all other, it's really 2 major areas which is Vapor and Niconovum. We're obviously in investment mode in both of those businesses for Reynolds American. Niconovum is certainly one area that we continue to rollout and ramp-up d
componenttext: Yes. I think, if you look at all other, it's really 2 major areas which is Vapor and Niconovum. We're obviously in investment mode in both of those businesses for Reynolds American. Niconovum is certainly one area that we continue to rollout and ramp-up distribution, and that certainly is playing into some of the numbers that you're seeing there. But we feel very comfortable with where we are on those 2 businesses given the opportunities that we see in the marketplace, and I think that's a pretty good view. We've come down significantly from first quarter of last year, we're making great strides on the efficiency book businesses and I think we are moving very -- in a very rapid pace towards turning those businesses into strong profit contributors.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question is from Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a quick question on shelf resets. In the goal displayed in your Q1 results, are you guys pleased with the incremental space you received with your new EDLP contract? Also, I assume that these were all completed in Q1, so do you think you could see
componenttext: I have a quick question on shelf resets. In the goal displayed in your Q1 results, are you guys pleased with the incremental space you received with your new EDLP contract? Also, I assume that these were all completed in Q1, so do you think you could see an even greater positive impact in Q2 and then for the remainder of the year?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Bonnie. We are very pleased with the space we have now. Remember, we still have a little bit of the handcuff going on here with ITG and the amount of space we can request, but we got the space we wanted in this round. And those -- the final o
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Bonnie. We are very pleased with the space we have now. Remember, we still have a little bit of the handcuff going on here with ITG and the amount of space we can request, but we got the space we wanted in this round. And those -- the final opportunity comes at the end of this year in the context of hunting for even more space. Having said that, we got the right -- you've seen the numbers, we were pleased with the percentage of retailers that chose to use -- to go on the EDLP contract and the merchandising set themselves. We would say that they are mostly complete now through April. And so, certainly, as we look into the second quarter and beyond, we do expect to generate some business with those sets being complete.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I have a question on Pall Mall and Camel. So I wanted to get a sense from you if you're pleased with the performance of these brands and do you think they've benefited from the addition of Newport in your portfolio? So I'm j
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I have a question on Pall Mall and Camel. So I wanted to get a sense from you if you're pleased with the performance of these brands and do you think they've benefited from the addition of Newport in your portfolio? So I'm just curious if you think there's been a positive halo effect for these brands?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's early to say that, to be honest, as we just finished these resets, particularly in the juxtaposition of these geographies. But I would say, when you look at Camel, it is sequentially up. We did take a hit last year with those -- when we had t
componenttext: I think it's early to say that, to be honest, as we just finished these resets, particularly in the juxtaposition of these geographies. But I would say, when you look at Camel, it is sequentially up. We did take a hit last year with those -- when we had to withdraw Camel Crush Bold and we did not spend the same dollars on Camel in the first quarter that we did a year ago. So we are pleased with the Camel's performance and we believe that, that will continue to improve. Again, looking at Pall Mall, while Pall Mall was down 3/10 of a share point versus a year ago, basically Pall Mall has been flat since about April last year, and so we feel good about that. I mean, in an environment where consumers are trading up to premium, we don't believe spending a lot of resources to grow value is a good use of resource. And Pall Mall is holding its own and we are making equity investment, and it continues to be the nation's #1 value brand. So we are pleased with both of those brands and I do think that we will see some change in the dynamic as these sets really get up and running, and we'll certainly keep you posted.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bonnie, I would just add that beyond the new sets, obviously, expansion of EDLP and we have seen some pretty robust expansion of the EDLP contract, we do expect that to benefit Pall Mall and Camel over time. But that is not something that we would see imm
componenttext: Bonnie, I would just add that beyond the new sets, obviously, expansion of EDLP and we have seen some pretty robust expansion of the EDLP contract, we do expect that to benefit Pall Mall and Camel over time. But that is not something that we would see immediate changes on that, that would be something that as those resources come in and consumers are made aware of that and the presence improves and so on, so we would expect a lot of that to come throughout this year as those changes are implemented and the awareness increases within those stores.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes a lot of sense. And then I just have a final follow-on question regarding promos and margins. Susan, you mentioned earlier that Q1 marketing spending was light, but this could be more of a timing issue. So I guess, I'm trying to get a sen
componenttext: Okay. That makes a lot of sense. And then I just have a final follow-on question regarding promos and margins. Susan, you mentioned earlier that Q1 marketing spending was light, but this could be more of a timing issue. So I guess, I'm trying to get a sense for the levels of spending we could expect for the remainder of the year. Does your guidance assume greater marketing spend versus last year, for instance?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to go there, Bonnie, in terms of exactly what our marketing programs are going forward. But I think the relevant point is, just as you're looking at last quarter versus this quarter and the performance and the dollars spent, obviously, Newpo
componenttext: I'm not going to go there, Bonnie, in terms of exactly what our marketing programs are going forward. But I think the relevant point is, just as you're looking at last quarter versus this quarter and the performance and the dollars spent, obviously, Newport always had its heavy investment in quarter 1, and our investment on Newport is spread more across the 4 quarters. So that's just as an example. But we're looking at certainly competitive levels of marketing support.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just on industry volume trends, Susan. Just -- obviously, trends have come in better even as we're lapping some of the positive tailwinds. So do you think that maybe down 2% that you were expecting at the beginning of the year is now certainly pote
componenttext: First, just on industry volume trends, Susan. Just -- obviously, trends have come in better even as we're lapping some of the positive tailwinds. So do you think that maybe down 2% that you were expecting at the beginning of the year is now certainly potential for upside to that number? And then is there any sort of data that gives you more clarity in terms of more recent drivers? Is it frequency, penetration? Because it seems like even as we're lapping kind of the consumers having more money from lower gas prices to wage growth, all of that is abating, to some extent, and we're still seeing pretty healthy industry volume trend.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Judy, I would say that the macro -- the macros like the lower gas prices, the raise of the minimum wage, these are positively impacting the disposable income of the tobacco consumer and you continue to see people sort of trading up. And so when you s
componenttext: Yes. Judy, I would say that the macro -- the macros like the lower gas prices, the raise of the minimum wage, these are positively impacting the disposable income of the tobacco consumer and you continue to see people sort of trading up. And so when you so these combustible volumes, you understand that there are some categories, bags of tobacco and roll your own, and these sorts of things where people are -- there are not more people consuming cigarettes, so that's not the driver there. But people are trading up to premium, and in some context, that means trading up to combustible. So we feel good about those macros. To your point, we modeled certainly our guidance on a 2% to 3% industry decline. The first quarter was flat on an adjusted basis. As we get into the half, certainly, we are already thinking that that's going to be certainly to the lower end of our anticipated decline, but we will reevaluate that once we get through the half.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Andrew, I wanted to understand a little bit more specifically the margin improvement that we saw on the RJRT side. And certainly, the cost synergies played a role and pricing has been positive, but you also talked about some of the other in
componenttext: Okay. And then Andrew, I wanted to understand a little bit more specifically the margin improvement that we saw on the RJRT side. And certainly, the cost synergies played a role and pricing has been positive, but you also talked about some of the other internal efforts that potentially drove some of that margin improvement and it seems like sequentially we also saw the improvement there, too. So can you just maybe quantify some of these big buckets of cost savings and to the extent that you can identify where these savings have hit between cost and SG&A?  Because it seems like most of that really hit cost and I would have thought from a cost synergy perspective, it's more SG&A initially and then moving to cost as we get the manufacturing integration completed.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, to your point, obviously, the Newport acquisition played a major role on that. We are seeing synergies come through. The cost synergies are playing out as we anticipated, so you're seeing benefits from that. The net price realization, we tal
componenttext: Yes. I think, to your point, obviously, the Newport acquisition played a major role on that. We are seeing synergies come through. The cost synergies are playing out as we anticipated, so you're seeing benefits from that. The net price realization, we talk about 14%. About half of that was mix, about half of that was actually pricing. So we've seen very robust pricing coming through on the margins. And really, on the internal side, we continue to drive efficiencies throughout our business so some of that is coming through in our manufacturing environment. We have a number of different initiatives that are aimed at optimizing our processes and operations, as well as our supply chain. But we also have a number of other information technology-type initiatives that are aimed at optimizing some of our spend internally here. So all of that is playing out, I think, over time. And I think it continues to be a very strong story for us in terms of our operating margins, not just pricing, it's actually coming through in more efficient operations as well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Andrew, just my final follow-up on all others. That's -- the decline sort of on a year-over-year or backup growth in terms of the revenue side of it, is that reflective of just the elimination of Santa Fe international?
componenttext: Okay. And then, Andrew, just my final follow-up on all others. That's -- the decline sort of on a year-over-year or backup growth in terms of the revenue side of it, is that reflective of just the elimination of Santa Fe international?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's -- we continue to see sales growth in both Vapor and Niconovum, but obviously, it is reflective of not having our international business within that segment.
componenttext: Yes. That's -- we continue to see sales growth in both Vapor and Niconovum, but obviously, it is reflective of not having our international business within that segment.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's about $30 million per quarter?
componenttext: And that's about $30 million per quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that right in front of me, Judy. So I can follow-up with you off-line on that.
componenttext: I don't have that right in front of me, Judy. So I can follow-up with you off-line on that.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That would be high. Got it. Okay. All right, I'll follow-up.
componenttext: Yes. That would be high. Got it. Okay. All right, I'll follow-up.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Lavery with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just elaborate a little bit on the significant strength in Natural American Spirit? And specifically, a couple of things, one is, did it get any extra shelf space from resets? And especially if it didn't, then what are some of the drivers there
componenttext: Could you just elaborate a little bit on the significant strength in Natural American Spirit? And specifically, a couple of things, one is, did it get any extra shelf space from resets? And especially if it didn't, then what are some of the drivers there just given the particularly strong comp in this quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, we continue to be very pleased with Natural American Spirit. And we are seeing -- most of this growth is actually same-store sales growth, because much of that distribution expansion had occurred as we lapped this quarter. We are also pleased wit
componenttext: Michael, we continue to be very pleased with Natural American Spirit. And we are seeing -- most of this growth is actually same-store sales growth, because much of that distribution expansion had occurred as we lapped this quarter. We are also pleased with the space that Natural American Spirit did retain in the context of this new round of contract, and this is really the consumer trading up to premium. And Natural American Spirit, of course, has a very distinctive positioning. It's a distinctive product and it hit that 2 share point mark. And as we've talked before, it's not really 2 share points anywhere. It has strong popularity in many of the -- in many cities around the country and it's continuing to grow in just about every state. So I think it's just -- it's course -- it's on course.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just given, like you said the disparity in market shares, are you seeing geographic expansion momentum? I mean, obviously, you called out the same-store sales, but is that giving any sort of indirect effect of just better momentum to move into new ter
componenttext: And just given, like you said the disparity in market shares, are you seeing geographic expansion momentum? I mean, obviously, you called out the same-store sales, but is that giving any sort of indirect effect of just better momentum to move into new territories or to develop in places where it's underpenetrated?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It has very broad distribution today. I would say that there is not so much more to go in terms of storefront. What we do see is opportunity to increase the number of styles in the stores where we have the distribution. And of course, as the core styles p
componenttext: It has very broad distribution today. I would say that there is not so much more to go in terms of storefront. What we do see is opportunity to increase the number of styles in the stores where we have the distribution. And of course, as the core styles pick up, it enables us to add styles into that range. But I think, it's on track and the growth year-over-year is tremendous. And of course, there is also sequential growth. But Natural American Spirit has been -- it had this momentum now for probably at least 10 quarters. And I don't see it slowing down.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I would just add that the growth that we're seeing is broad-based. It's across the entire U.S. It's in areas where it is overdeveloped. It's in the areas where it's under development. It's really across all of various states, East and West. So we
componenttext: Michael, I would just add that the growth that we're seeing is broad-based. It's across the entire U.S. It's in areas where it is overdeveloped. It's in the areas where it's under development. It's really across all of various states, East and West. So we're very pleased with that, but there's nothing really unique about this quarter versus some of the past quarters.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just on the margins for Santa Fe, too, the comp obviously was very tough and you still put up a nice big boost. Is that primarily -- I know you had the good pricing, but is operating leverage a big piece of that? Or what's k
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just on the margins for Santa Fe, too, the comp obviously was very tough and you still put up a nice big boost. Is that primarily -- I know you had the good pricing, but is operating leverage a big piece of that? Or what's kind of the trajectory for the year in terms of what some of the drivers are and what to think looking ahead?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think for Santa Fe it's pretty straightforward, it really is pricing. And we, obviously, don't discount that brand so pricing is a significant component. And then, obviously, we continue to get efficiencies because of the higher volume in the large
componenttext: Yes. I think for Santa Fe it's pretty straightforward, it really is pricing. And we, obviously, don't discount that brand so pricing is a significant component. And then, obviously, we continue to get efficiencies because of the higher volume in the larger scale, so all of that is playing into seeing operating margins continue to grow.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just lastly, can you give anymore color, I know you've touched on this a little bit and you've got the August debt that you plan on paying down. But after the dividend hike and the tender, is buybacks the next priority? And
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just lastly, can you give anymore color, I know you've touched on this a little bit and you've got the August debt that you plan on paying down. But after the dividend hike and the tender, is buybacks the next priority? And is there any timing you could give on when we might be able to expect those?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, as we set this out, we've laid out our priorities really being our balance sheet metrics. And I think, we've been very sort of methodical in trying to address those balance sheet metrics. We first hit our pension, as you know. In January, we had
componenttext: I think, as we set this out, we've laid out our priorities really being our balance sheet metrics. And I think, we've been very sort of methodical in trying to address those balance sheet metrics. We first hit our pension, as you know. In January, we had $325 million to increase the fund of status there. This most recent tender and redemption was a big play for us and certainly got our leverage down into a range. The $500 million we do anticipate paying off at this point, we've reviewed that over the past few months and feel like we're in a good position to move forward with that. And I think as we get into that range, we certainly will be looking at our dividend policy and we will be looking at other ways to return capital to shareholders in the form of share repurchases and other opportunities. So nothing really has changed on that front. I think, we're trying to be very methodical in sort of addressing all of these priorities. It's never been a question of one versus the other, it's a matter of how do we sequence this and how we get to a position where we feel good about sort of the long-term plan. Though that -- I think that still is considered our position and then I think we're in a great spot heading into the back half of the year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, actually, just one last one on Newport. You talked about how it was growing in not menthol and non-menthol. Could you be specific about the non-full flavor menthol? I know you've called that as a potential opportunity, are you seeing impro
componenttext: Okay. And then, actually, just one last one on Newport. You talked about how it was growing in not menthol and non-menthol. Could you be specific about the non-full flavor menthol? I know you've called that as a potential opportunity, are you seeing improvement there as well?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are seeing improvement across the board in the context of these Newport style. And as I said, earlier, we will talk more about the marketing initiatives and the support for these various line extensions as we get into this year. But they're all perform
componenttext: We are seeing improvement across the board in the context of these Newport style. And as I said, earlier, we will talk more about the marketing initiatives and the support for these various line extensions as we get into this year. But they're all performing well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Growe with Stifel.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 questions, if I could, a bit of follow-on to some earlier questions. So the first one, and this is -- Vivien asked a question very similar of this. But I want -- your promotional spending was down overall, I think you mentioned in the quarter
componenttext: I just had 2 questions, if I could, a bit of follow-on to some earlier questions. So the first one, and this is -- Vivien asked a question very similar of this. But I want -- your promotional spending was down overall, I think you mentioned in the quarter. And I want to be clear, you said that was kind of contrary to the industry trend, I guess, just wanted to confirm that. And then just to understand when Newport goes into a new outlet or Camel and Pall Mall go into a new outlet, in those outlets are you seeing -- are you using promotional spending to get to a better price point to help drive some trial? Or -- and therefore, it's down another -- into your core markets, if you will, if that question make sense?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will take that question first. As we go into contracted outlets, part of that space contract is aligned with the amount of discounting that is available for Newport and Camel and Pall Mall. And so as you go into these new outlets, depending on the contr
componenttext: I will take that question first. As we go into contracted outlets, part of that space contract is aligned with the amount of discounting that is available for Newport and Camel and Pall Mall. And so as you go into these new outlets, depending on the contract that retailer has selected, will depend on the amount of price discounting and promotion for that outlet. So it's -- we've added -- and it's not as though these brands, to be honest, haven't been in the stores at all either. It is really more about display and awareness and promotional opportunity as we go across the country now with our national footprint and our merchandising agreements.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then was promotional spending overall, I think you said is down for Reynolds, but you believe it's up for the category overall, is that a fair characterization?
componenttext: Okay. And then was promotional spending overall, I think you said is down for Reynolds, but you believe it's up for the category overall, is that a fair characterization?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair characterization. As we looked at promotional volume, in particular, that is what we're talking about.
componenttext: I think that's a fair characterization. As we looked at promotional volume, in particular, that is what we're talking about.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a final question, if I could. You don't report on -- I don't know if they actually could report on a total menthol share. I guess, I'm trying to understand is Camel Menthol still performing well maybe in relation to Newport, maybe with thos
componenttext: Okay. And just a final question, if I could. You don't report on -- I don't know if they actually could report on a total menthol share. I guess, I'm trying to understand is Camel Menthol still performing well maybe in relation to Newport, maybe with those brands or getting a little more prominence? Is there any -- how is your overall menthol share performing if it's -- if you can answer that?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's performing very well and it is growing. And we will get into, as we come out in our Investor Days, we will talk more about how the styles of Camel are performing, et cetera. But Camel Menthol continues to perform and certainly, as I said, the majorit
componenttext: It's performing very well and it is growing. And we will get into, as we come out in our Investor Days, we will talk more about how the styles of Camel are performing, et cetera. But Camel Menthol continues to perform and certainly, as I said, the majority of Newport's growth is in premium menthol.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if any of these already been answered, but just had a few follow-ups. One, just from an industry standpoint, as we think about some of the tailwinds that had benefited cigarette volumes over the past 12 to 18 months, one of the key factors, de
componenttext: I apologize if any of these already been answered, but just had a few follow-ups. One, just from an industry standpoint, as we think about some of the tailwinds that had benefited cigarette volumes over the past 12 to 18 months, one of the key factors, definitely not the most important though, has been the shift within the trade away from e-cig and Vapor inventory back to combustibles. So I just wanted to get a sense at the stage on where we stand in that repositioning cycle within the trade and whether you think that can continue to be a tailwind for cigarette volumes?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say we're pretty well through that myself. We have seen over the last 9 months retailers reducing their volumes on e-cigarettes. VUSE, of course, is the #1 by 3x and a weak -- and VUSE is growing and we continue to see that and our flavor cartridg
componenttext: I would say we're pretty well through that myself. We have seen over the last 9 months retailers reducing their volumes on e-cigarettes. VUSE, of course, is the #1 by 3x and a weak -- and VUSE is growing and we continue to see that and our flavor cartridges are performing very well. But I think a lot of that inventory reduction has come out. And of course -- then it depends on the individual retailers, how they are working with their inventory. Certainly, nobody wants to be out of stock, but it's also heavy carrying cost. So that's something that is always has to be balanced. But certainly, the diversion from combustible to e-cigarette is long past.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as you're now in the process spend of launching some of the new VUSE products online, I was just curious how you think about the balance between being focused on that online distribution versus expanding more broadly back into the traditional re
componenttext: Okay. And as you're now in the process spend of launching some of the new VUSE products online, I was just curious how you think about the balance between being focused on that online distribution versus expanding more broadly back into the traditional retail channels? And what are the some of the indicators you would look before being willing to make that step?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, the indicators certainly are interest, and we are generating awareness. And certainly, we know that the retailers value their space and being sure that we have items that are worth deploying in their store is very important. So I think that we wi
componenttext: I think, the indicators certainly are interest, and we are generating awareness. And certainly, we know that the retailers value their space and being sure that we have items that are worth deploying in their store is very important. So I think that we will watch this offtake online and then decide if we want to roll it out in any sort of category of retailer.

componenttext: Okay. Thank you for your participation today. Before we sign off, I'd like to update you on one other matter. Morris Moore, our Vice President of Investor Relations, will be retiring at the end of May after 37 years of service with our company. He will be succeeded by Bob Bannon, who joined us from Lorillard last year. We will be meeting many of you in New York and London in the coming weeks, and I know you'll join me in wishing Morris the very best and then welcoming Bob to his new role. They've been working closely together, so we expect a seamless transition. Thank you for your interest in RAI.
