headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Denise, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Reynolds American third quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions]Thank you. Vice President of Investor R
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Denise, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Reynolds American third quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions]
Thank you. Vice President of Investor Relations, Bob Bannon, you may begin your conference.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the third quarter and 9 months as well as our revised outlook for the full year.As usual, our discussion will include adjusted non-GAAP results as mana
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our call. Today, we'll review Reynolds American's results for the third quarter and 9 months as well as our revised outlook for the full year.
As usual, our discussion will include adjusted non-GAAP results as management believes this provides additional perspective on our underlying business performance. RAI's use of adjusted measurements are intended to be supplemental in nature and should not be viewed as a substitute for reported GAAP results. Our press release includes an explanation of our use of adjusted EPS guidance and reconciliations of reported to adjusted results. Our press release is available on our website at reynoldsamerican.com.
Joining me this morning are RAI's President and CEO, Susan Cameron; R.J. Reynolds' President and COO, Debra Crew, who, as you saw this morning, has been named RAI's President and CEO elect; and we also have Andrew Gilchrist, our CFO.
The information we're about to discuss includes forward-looking statements. When we talk about future results or events, a number of factors could generate results that are materially different from our projections today. These factors include, but are not limited to, items detailed in our press release and SEC filings. Except as provided by federal securities laws, we are not required to publicly update or revise any forward-looking or cautionary statements. I'd also remind you that RAI's website is our primary source of publicly disclosed news and that we also use Twitter to disseminate company news.
And now I'll turn the call over to Susan.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Hello, everyone. Well, we do have plenty of news today, don't we? But before I speak to the upcoming changes in leadership here, let me touch on a few of the quarter's business highlights.First, our operating performance continued to be
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Hello, everyone. Well, we do have plenty of news today, don't we? But before I speak to the upcoming changes in leadership here, let me touch on a few of the quarter's business highlights.
First, our operating performance continued to be excellent, especially in light of the significant investments in our company's regulatory compliance, innovation pipeline and participation in current state political processes. In addition, both Newport and Natural American Spirit made another impressive showing in the marketplace. And together, with higher pricing in both cigarettes and moist snuff, these premium brands were a key driver behind RAI's strong earnings growth for the third quarter and the first 9 months.
Over the course of the year, we've also accelerated returns to our shareholders. And I'd remind you here of our significant debt reduction, 2 dividend increases and RAI's new share repurchase program. So I'm very pleased with the way this year has progressed. And with Newport's integration now behind us, this is an appropriate time to lay out our leadership succession plans.
As we announced today, I will become Executive Chairman of RAI on the 1st of January, and Debra will succeed me as President and CEO. Yes, I really am retiring as CEO this time, and I've assured my husband there will be no round 3. But I'm fully committed to making a seamless and successful transition with Debra over the next few months. And as board chair, I look forward to play an integral role in RAI's future success.
Not only is this the right time for a transition to new roles, but Debra is absolutely the right person to lead RAI and its companies to the next level. Debra has years of experience and leadership in the consumer products industry, and she has made a significant impact since joining R.J. Reynolds 2 years ago, playing a critical role in Newport's integration into our company's portfolio and helping to drive innovation throughout RAI's businesses. Debra and I have worked closely over the past 2 years, and I am confident that Debra will successfully build upon the strong foundation for our businesses that we have formed together following the Lorillard acquisition.
I also want to welcome Joseph Fragnito from the Kraft Heinz Company to RAI's leadership team. Joe, an experienced brand marketeer and innovator, will take over as R.J. Reynolds' President and Chief Commercial Officer next week. We will be giving you a full update on our plans to continue growing our businesses and advancing our transforming tobacco agenda at our Investment Day event in November.
So for now, I'll hand over to Debra for more details on our third quarter report.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Susan. It's great to be here, and I'm excited to be given the opportunity to play a bigger role in RAI's ongoing success. It has been a true pleasure over the past 2 years working with our talented team, gaining a deep understanding of the toba
componenttext:
Thank you, Susan. It's great to be here, and I'm excited to be given the opportunity to play a bigger role in RAI's ongoing success. It has been a true pleasure over the past 2 years working with our talented team, gaining a deep understanding of the tobacco industry as well as directly contributing to the success of our strong businesses and powerful brands.
I'd also like to welcome Joe and his expertise and experience to our team. From his work at Kraft Heinz, he knows how to run effective and efficient business units, in addition to his experience in consumer packaged goods. Joe also comes to R.J. Reynolds with a strong track record of bringing brand innovations to market, which will serve the company well moving forward.
In addition to working closely with Susan on the CEO transition, I and the rest of the leadership team look forward to working closely with Joe as we continue to build our company's businesses and execute upon our successful strategies now in place.
Now let's turn to our operating company's results. I'm sure you've all read our earnings report, so I just like to touch on the third quarter highlights and key takeaways. I'll start with combustibles.
We continued to see a positive macroeconomic environment for adult tobacco consumers in the third quarter. But we are now lapping the impact of those positive tailwinds on industry cigarette volumes, and we are seeing industry volumes returning to a more normal rate of decline.
On an inventory adjusted basis, industry cigarette volumes declined by about 3.4% for the quarter and about 1.8% for the first 9 months. Given this, our current view for the full year is that cigarette volumes will be down around 2.5%. And looking ahead, we continue to expect cigarette volume declines to track within their historical range of down 2% to 4%.
For RAI's operating companies, total third quarter cigarette volume was down by 1.5% from the prior year quarter and wholesale inventory changes did not have a significant impact on our operating companies in the quarter. Total third quarter retail cigarette market share for RAI's operating companies increased 0.3 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 34.6%, with their combined drive brands adding 0.4 percentage points to 32.2%. And these drive brands currently make up 93% of our operating company's total cigarette market share.
At R.J. Reynolds, third quarter cigarette shipments fell by 2.5% from the prior year quarter. And after adjusting for wholesale inventory movements, R.J. Reynolds' third quarter shipments declined by about 2.7%. And again, that was versus the industry adjusted decline of about 3.4%. Total cigarette market share at R.J. Reynolds in the third quarter was in line compared to the third quarter of last year at 32.3%.
Newport, the nation's #1 menthol brand, continues to demonstrate outstanding momentum following its inclusion in R.J. Reynolds' new retail contracts over the past year. Newport's volume in the third quarter was up about 1% versus the prior year and was not significantly impacted by wholesale inventory changes. We were also very pleased with Newport's continued strength at retail as the brand increased its third quarter retail market share by 0.4 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 13.9%. I would note that we continue to see Newport's market share growth coming across all geographies and from both its core menthol styles as well as its non-menthol styles.
R.J. Reynolds' Camel brand also continues to benefit from an improved national presence resulting from expanded retail contracts, offset by the impact from the removal of Camel styles associated with the FDA's not substantially equivalent decision in the fourth quarter of last year. As a result, Camel's third quarter retail cigarette market share was down 0.1 share points versus the prior year quarter at 8.3%. However, since the FDA decision last year, we have been very pleased that Camel has steadily grown market share from 8.1% to the 8.3% we saw in the third quarter. And R.J. Reynolds has exciting plans for the Camel Turkish family, aimed at building the brand's equity and growing Camel's market share. We will be providing more detail in that regard at our upcoming Investor Day presentation in New York next month.
Pall Mall, the nation's #1 value brand, continues to play an important role in the company's total portfolio strategy. And we are very pleased by its increasing profitability and contribution to the bottom line. In the current environment, with many adult smokers trading up into premium brands, Pall Mall's third quarter retail market share was down 0.2 percentage points versus the prior year but was in line with the second quarter of this year at 7.7%.
At Santa Fe, Natural American Spirit's distinctive premium brand continues to outperform. In the third quarter, the brand increased retail market share to 2.3%, which is an increase of 0.3 percentage points from the prior year quarter. And looking forward, we expect continued growth from Natural American Spirit as the brand benefits from increased consumer engagement and growing awareness of the brand's unique values.
At American Snuff, Grizzly's Dark Mint, which combines the richer and bolder taste of its dark styles with the popular mint flavor, was successfully expanded nationally late in the third quarter. The differentiated Dark Mint style has been very well received by consumers and should continue to benefit Grizzly going forward.
Grizzly's retail market share of 30.7% in the third quarter was up 0.2 percentage points sequentially and declined by 0.4 percentage points compared to a very strong third quarter of last year. Grizzly also continues to lead the growing pouch category, which now makes up more than 20% of the moist snuff industry, and the brand is the clear leader in Wintergreen, which is the largest flavor category. We continue to be very confident in Grizzly's strong underlying trends, its authentic product proposition, its highly loyal consumer base and its ability to deliver sustainable, profitable growth over both the near and long term.
Before we move on to Andrew, I'll give you a quick update on RAI Innovations and its subsidiaries, which are working hard on their mission to redefine the vapor category. RJR Vapor, whose VUSE digital vapor cigarettes continue to grow volume and lead the category with market share more than 3x its closest competitor in traditional retail channels, will expand availability of VUSE VIBE next month. VIBE, an exciting new format for the VUSE family of products, is a high-capacity, closed-cartridge tank system with a rechargeable battery. VIBE offers more liquid than the brand's previous products and also has a more powerful and longer-lasting battery. So it meets the desires we heard from adult tobacco consumers to combine the ease of use of a cigalike product with the performance of a tank system.
In the third quarter, RAI Innovations invested significantly in a variety of vapor platforms as well as in the regulatory support behind them. And you'll hear more about the company's innovations pipeline in the coming months.
Niconovum's Zonnic nicotine replacement therapy gum also continues to perform well. As you know, the brand rolled out a 10-count mini lozenge in selected stores in the third quarter, and this style is now available in about 19,000 outlets.
So that's a quick look at our operating company's achievements in the latest quarter and over the first 9 months of the year. We started the year with a robust plan for growth and a focus on strengthening our premium portfolio of drive brands. And we are on plan against those objectives. We also have exciting plans in place to further build upon this success, and we are confident that our businesses will continue to deliver on our objectives for future growth.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Debra, and good morning, everyone. Reynolds American had a very successful first 9 months of the year with strong financial performance across each of its operating companies, along with the successful completion of our integration process.To
componenttext:
Thank you, Debra, and good morning, everyone. Reynolds American had a very successful first 9 months of the year with strong financial performance across each of its operating companies, along with the successful completion of our integration process.
To start off, I'll cover our financial results for the quarter and year-to-date period. RAI's third quarter reported EPS increased by 30.4% from the prior year quarter to $0.60. As you know, this comparison includes the impact of the implementation and asset impairment costs last year. On an adjusted basis, third quarter EPS was $0.61, up 10.9% from the prior year quarter, benefiting from higher net pricing in both cigarettes and smokeless. This adjusted EPS excludes a charge of $0.01 per share related to Engle progeny lawsuits.
For the first 9 months, reported EPS was $3.65, up 49% from the prior year period. Adjusted EPS over the first 9 months was $1.69, which was up 12.7%. These 9-month adjusted results also reflect charges of $0.03 per share related to Engle progeny lawsuits as well as a gain of $2.11 per share related to the sale of Natural American Spirit's international business and charges of $0.12 per share for debt and financing costs and implementation costs.
RAI's third quarter adjusted operating margin continued to expand, increasing 4.1 percentage points to 48.5%, demonstrating the enhanced strength and profitability of our company's businesses. That brought first 9 months adjusted operating margin to 46.6%, up 4.9 percentage points from last year's first 9 months.
Now let's take a look at our operating company's performance where I'll discuss adjusted results, where applicable. Please refer to schedules 2 and 3 at the end of our earnings release for a detailed reconciliation of our reported to adjusted results.
R.J. Reynolds continued to perform extremely well in the third quarter, with reported operating income up by almost 16% at just over $1.3 billion. The company benefited from solid net price realization of 3.9% in the third quarter compared to the prior year quarter. Please note that R.J. Reynolds' calculated net pricing for the third quarter does include a negative year-over-year impact resulting from the completed reciprocal manufacturing agreement with ITG Brands. Excluding the impact, R.J. Reynolds' net pricing would have been over 5% for the quarter.
On an adjusted basis, the company's third quarter operating income increased by 8.7% from the prior year quarter to $1.3 billion. This reflects a charge of $25 million for Engle progeny lawsuits and $3 million for implementation costs.
For the first 9 months, reported operating income was $3.6 billion, and that was up 48.6% from this time last year. 9-month adjusted operating income came in at $3.7 billion, a 37.5% increase from last year.
R.J. Reynolds also continued to strengthen its adjusted operating margin, which grew by 3.7 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 50.4%, an all-time high for the company. R.J. Reynolds' strong margin improvement in the quarter was largely driven by the net pricing, the synergy realization related to the Lorillard transaction and the company's continued focus on operating efficiencies and productivity improvement.
As we touched on previously, wholesale inventory levels impacted industry volume declines in the third quarter compared to the third quarter of last year. Wholesale inventories for the industry were approximately 8.1 billion units at the end of third quarter this year, representing an increase of more than 1.2 billion units during the quarter. This compares to industry inventories of 7.6 billion units at the end of the third quarter last year, which remained stable over the course of that quarter. This dynamic helped moderate the industry volume decline to only 1.6% for the third quarter, a number that would adjust down to 3.4% when factoring in the impact of the inventory changes.
At R.J. Reynolds, the inventories of approximately 2.3 billion at the end of third quarter remained relatively stable versus third quarter of last year as well as over each quarter since the completion of the Lorillard acquisition.
Now moving on to Santa Fe, where another quarter of very strong performance was supported by higher pricing and volume growth of 15.7%. Santa Fe increased its third quarter operating income by 27.7% to $154 million, and that brought operating income for the first 9 months to $410 million, up 21.6% over the first 9 months of the prior year. Strong net price realization of 5% in the third quarter drove the company's operating margin up by 2.7 percentage points to 57.9% for the quarter.
American Snuff reported another good quarter with volume growth of over 2% and net pricing realization of more than 9%. The company's third quarter operating income of $134 million was up 10.9% from the prior year quarter. And that resulted in an operating income in the first 9 months of $405 million, which was up by 10% from the prior year period. American Snuff's third quarter operating margin decreased slightly by 0.3 percentage points from the prior year quarter to 57.2%.
So that wraps up the summary of our company's performance. Now I'll provide a quick update on our long-term debt position.
RAI ended the quarter with $1.9 billion in cash balances, which takes into account the repayment of the company's $500 million bond that matured on August 4. This reduction in RAI's total outstanding debt, along with the continued growth in our businesses, has now brought the company within the top end of its long-term target leverage range of 1.5x to 2.5x total debt-to-EBITDA. I would note here that given the relatively low interest rate outlook, along with our improving interest coverage, the company remains comfortable operating at the higher end of this target leverage range.
As we discussed last quarter, RAI's board of directors approved an increase in our target dividend payout ratio back to 80% of adjusted net income. And our board also approved an increase in our quarterly cash dividend of 9.5% to $0.46 per share, which was paid on October 3. This quarter's dividend increase follows the 16.7% increase announced in February and is the third dividend increase since we completed the Lorillard acquisition last June. The company also began to implement its recently announced $2 billion share repurchase program, with repurchases of approximately $75 million of RAI common stock during the quarter. The program is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2018.
These actions clearly demonstrate the company's commitment to returning tangible value to our shareholders as well as the confidence that RAI's management and board have in our operating company's business strategies and performance going forward. And we remain focused on finding opportunities to further enhance shareholder value in a consistent and disciplined manner.
Now that we have reached the 9-month mark for the year, we're narrowing the range of RAI's 2016 adjusted EPS guidance by $0.02 to a new range of $2.27 to $2.33, which is up 14.6% to 17.7% over last year's adjusted EPS.
So all in all, we are pleased with how our businesses have performed in the quarter and over the first 9 months. We're also happy to be meeting our growth objectives for the year, particularly given the increased investments in innovation, regulation and state political engagements.
Thank you all. Now we'll turn to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, would you remind our callers how to get into the queue?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Vivien Azer with Cowen.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Susan, Debra, congratulations on your evolving roles. I just wanted to start off with a discussion on Newport. Given the deceleration that we've seen in terms of the market share gains over the course of the quarter, can you talk a little bit about how
componenttext: So Susan, Debra, congratulations on your evolving roles. I just wanted to start off with a discussion on Newport. Given the deceleration that we've seen in terms of the market share gains over the course of the quarter, can you talk a little bit about how you're thinking about price gap management and promotional spending on the brand?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. It's Debra. Look, I think Newport, we still feel very, very pleased with how the brand is performing. I think when you think about Newport, think about the year versus just the quarter. We're actually up year-to-date 0.5 percentage po
componenttext: Thank you very much. It's Debra. Look, I think Newport, we still feel very, very pleased with how the brand is performing. I think when you think about Newport, think about the year versus just the quarter. We're actually up year-to-date 0.5 percentage points on share. For the quarter, it was still up 0.4. And also, I think one of the things that really pleases us is that the growth we're seeing in both menthol and in non-menthol as well as across all geographies. So we're still seeing that. Of course, we are starting to lap the stronger performance that we had last year. So I think that the deceleration in growth, I think, that you're seeing is really kind of a lapping of stronger performance of prior year as well. I think as far as price gap management pricing, the question there, pricing within the quarter was in line with where we've seen it. We did not add or take away any promotional spending. It was about on kind of average of where we've been. So there hasn't been any changes there on Newport.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. That's helpful. Andrew, I had a question for you, please, on the nonoperating items. I mean, clearly, the margin expansion, the profit growth was good and better than I was looking for on the EBIT line, but clearly a lot of moving pieces in term
componenttext: Terrific. That's helpful. Andrew, I had a question for you, please, on the nonoperating items. I mean, clearly, the margin expansion, the profit growth was good and better than I was looking for on the EBIT line, but clearly a lot of moving pieces in terms of some of the spend you guys had around political engagement that you called out. So how should we think about that for the remainder of the year, please?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say, Vivien, really, the engagements on the state political process generally were third quarter. There will be some run-on effect in -- obviously, in October. But generally, those were concentrated in the third quarter. Regulatory, on the ot
componenttext: Yes, I would say, Vivien, really, the engagements on the state political process generally were third quarter. There will be some run-on effect in -- obviously, in October. But generally, those were concentrated in the third quarter. Regulatory, on the other hand, I think is something that will be with us ongoing. So some of those expenses really started with the deeming regs as we got clarity on some of that regulation. We have ramped up some spending on that to make sure that we're compliant and that we're continuing to drive innovation through our business. But we see that as something that probably will continue on, certainly, for the next year.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Susan and Debra, as well. So I guess first question to Andrew, just on the guidance range, which you narrowed, but it still has a fair amount of flexibility to -- or around that $0.07. Could you just speak to what you see at some of the k
componenttext: Congratulations, Susan and Debra, as well. So I guess first question to Andrew, just on the guidance range, which you narrowed, but it still has a fair amount of flexibility to -- or around that $0.07. Could you just speak to what you see at some of the key variables that could move you to the lower -- higher end of the range still within the fourth quarter?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thanks for the question, Matt. I think, obviously, we narrowed it down to $2.27 to $2.33, which, as we stated, is up 14.7% to 17.7%. So we're -- we continue to feel very good about that. Certainly, the midpoint of that range continues to be con
componenttext: Yes. Well, thanks for the question, Matt. I think, obviously, we narrowed it down to $2.27 to $2.33, which, as we stated, is up 14.7% to 17.7%. So we're -- we continue to feel very good about that. Certainly, the midpoint of that range continues to be consistent with where we were at the beginning of the year. And there's inherent variability in the business. So obviously, with volumes, we have seen a significant shift in volumes, I think, throughout the year. It's been relatively consistent with where we've been from a plan standpoint. We talked about 2% at the beginning of the year. I think, right now, best estimate is between 2% and 2.5%. That's probably a good view. But obviously, we still have 1 quarter to go, and we'll have to see how that plays out. But we also have other regulatory costs, and we'll have to just see how this plays out for the remainder of the quarter. But all in all, we're very pleased with how the year has gone. We're very pleased with the 14.7% to 17.7% growth that we've laid out in terms of our guidance range. And we've still got 1 quarter to go, but we feel good about where we are.

And I realize that you had a difficult comparison to the prior year, but just the overlay of those 2 factors.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say, Matt, I think on American Snuff, remembering that some of this is just simply timing. So we launched Grizzly Dark at, really, the tail end of this quarter. So certainly, that was at kind of full price, and that drove up some of that net
componenttext: I would just say, Matt, I think on American Snuff, remembering that some of this is just simply timing. So we launched Grizzly Dark at, really, the tail end of this quarter. So certainly, that was at kind of full price, and that drove up some of that net price realization really for third quarter. But most of the activity, of course, on Dark will come and the benefit on share will really come in the upcoming quarters.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, I'd just add, I don't think there's been any change in philosophy on Grizzly at all. Our focus is to continue to grow that brand, continue to grow market share on that brand. We think we can do that in a very profitable way. We've got margins that a
componenttext: Matt, I'd just add, I don't think there's been any change in philosophy on Grizzly at all. Our focus is to continue to grow that brand, continue to grow market share on that brand. We think we can do that in a very profitable way. We've got margins that are north of 55%, and our focus is to continue to drive growth both in volume and market share.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from of Nik Modi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from of Nik Modi.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to echo everyone else's congratulations. Quick question on the non-core Newport styles. Maybe you'll talk about this more at the Analyst Day, but can you just provide some thoughts on kind of how you're thinking of strategically positioning those 2
componenttext: I want to echo everyone else's congratulations. Quick question on the non-core Newport styles. Maybe you'll talk about this more at the Analyst Day, but can you just provide some thoughts on kind of how you're thinking of strategically positioning those 2 brands? Have you had some time to kind of review their positioning, et cetera?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Nik, as you said, we will be talking more about this and the broader portfolio strategy on Newport at our upcoming Investor Day, and we can certainly provide a lot more color than -- I think we talked about those, these -- the styles of Newport,
componenttext: Sure. So Nik, as you said, we will be talking more about this and the broader portfolio strategy on Newport at our upcoming Investor Day, and we can certainly provide a lot more color than -- I think we talked about those, these -- the styles of Newport, both menthol, and we are finding non-menthol also to be quite important to the franchise, and it's certainly working in a different way in our portfolio from some of our other brands. We like the geographic development of some of the Newport non-menthol as well as the demographic of that adult tobacco consumer really works for us. And it's quite complementary to the rest of the portfolio. So we'll talk a little bit. We've got the Newport Smooth Select that we talked about at our last Investor Day and some of the moves we're making on that to kind of make that a little more relevant in the portfolio. But certainly, we can provide some more color on that in November.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the Camel brand. Obviously, things have been improving sequentially. What's really driving that? Is it primarily the menthol side? Or is there other core styles that are doing better?
componenttext: Great. And then on the Camel brand. Obviously, things have been improving sequentially. What's really driving that? Is it primarily the menthol side? Or is there other core styles that are doing better?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It is mostly the menthol -- the Camel Crush is doing very well. But I will also say our Camel Classic style has stabilized as well. So we're feeling great about that. We talked about in this call the upcoming Turkish expansion that we plan on doing.
componenttext: Yes. It is mostly the menthol -- the Camel Crush is doing very well. But I will also say our Camel Classic style has stabilized as well. So we're feeling great about that. We talked about in this call the upcoming Turkish expansion that we plan on doing. And once again, we can talk about the broader portfolio strategy on Camel in November as well. But I think, really, what's driving the growth is the Crush style but also that stabilization of Classics.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Adam Spielman with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Adam Spielman with Citi.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I actually have 2 questions. The first is about the difference between the underlying volume growth of the industry, which I think you said was down 3.4%, and the scanner data, which is significantly less bad than that. And I'd always been under the impre
componenttext: I actually have 2 questions. The first is about the difference between the underlying volume growth of the industry, which I think you said was down 3.4%, and the scanner data, which is significantly less bad than that. And I'd always been under the impression that MSAi data is actually a little bit better to break even Nielsen data. So I was wondering if you can talk about difference and why you think it occurs.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Adam, this is Andrew. I'll give you, I think, some perspective, and I think this is important to understand as well. If you think about the 3.4%, which is an inventory adjusted -- it's essentially a calculated number with inventory adjustments in thi
componenttext: Yes, Adam, this is Andrew. I'll give you, I think, some perspective, and I think this is important to understand as well. If you think about the 3.4%, which is an inventory adjusted -- it's essentially a calculated number with inventory adjustments in third quarter. We go back to second quarter, we had an inventory adjusted number of 1.7% decline. Because of some of the calendar differences between last year and this year, the way I would really think about that is if you look at the 2 quarters combined, they're roughly about 2.5% each. And I think that's probably the best indicator on actually where the industry is. So obviously, you have some different periods with scanner data and so on, but MSAi, I think, is certainly real volume, and certainly, this is just a calculated number. But from a general standpoint, the 2.5% is how we are thinking about it. And certainly, that 2% to 2.5% range that we've talked about for the full year is our expectation.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's extremely helpful. And the second question I had, and it echoes a brief comment Vivien made earlier. I was very surprised about how much margin expansion there was in RJRT in 3Q relative to the margin that you achieved in 2Q. And I was wonder
componenttext: Okay. That's extremely helpful. And the second question I had, and it echoes a brief comment Vivien made earlier. I was very surprised about how much margin expansion there was in RJRT in 3Q relative to the margin that you achieved in 2Q. And I was wondering if you could just talk about what was really driving that. And I guess if you could thread forward as well, that would help it. But really understanding why the margin expanded so much sequentially.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, it's a mix driving that. We certainly have had strong net price realization, including a price increase in second quarter that you saw. But generally, it's been driven by mix. And that is -- obviously, our fastest-growing brand at RJRT is
componenttext: Well, generally, it's a mix driving that. We certainly have had strong net price realization, including a price increase in second quarter that you saw. But generally, it's been driven by mix. And that is -- obviously, our fastest-growing brand at RJRT is Newport. And that happens to be our highest-margin product. So I think we're in a very good shape on that front.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And does that imply that in future quarters, we should see some sort of similar expansion? And I guess also, the other question is, how was this affected? We've talked about the adjustment from the reciprocal manufacturing agreement coming off. My guess i
componenttext: And does that imply that in future quarters, we should see some sort of similar expansion? And I guess also, the other question is, how was this affected? We've talked about the adjustment from the reciprocal manufacturing agreement coming off. My guess is that, that had an impact on margin as well. But it's obviously pretty technical, and I -- some explanation would be lovely.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right. But I would say, obviously, we're seeing full synergies here going forward as well. So third quarter was generally -- as we talked about, we were working through the inventories, and we did that toward the end of the third quarter. W
componenttext: You're exactly right. But I would say, obviously, we're seeing full synergies here going forward as well. So third quarter was generally -- as we talked about, we were working through the inventories, and we did that toward the end of the third quarter. We got 2 inventories that are being manufactured by RJRT. So from a productivity standpoint, from a synergy standpoint, all of that is certainly adding to our margin improvement, and that's an incremental and certainly a sequential sort of improvement that we've seen in the business.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Susan and Debra, again. I just wanted to ask a question, a bit of a follow-on. I think you just indicated, Andrew, that you did have full synergies in the quarter. And I guess I was curious, was there anything to the timing of synergies?
componenttext: Congratulations, Susan and Debra, again. I just wanted to ask a question, a bit of a follow-on. I think you just indicated, Andrew, that you did have full synergies in the quarter. And I guess I was curious, was there anything to the timing of synergies? Or can we talk about some of the expenses that could be affected in the quarter that would have negatively affected RJRT's profits in the quarter? So anything around synergies or the timing of expenses.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question. Just so we're clear on synergies. So full synergies will be in fourth quarter going forward. Third quarter, we were still working down inventories that were manufactured at ITG. So the full run rate will be fourth quarter goi
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. Just so we're clear on synergies. So full synergies will be in fourth quarter going forward. Third quarter, we were still working down inventories that were manufactured at ITG. So the full run rate will be fourth quarter going forward, but obviously, we got there toward the end of third quarter. As far as the expenses, really, a couple areas. Certainly, regulatory compliance and our state political process engagement were 2 incremental costs that came through in third quarter, and certainly, were concentrated in third quarter with some of the things that we were doing. So if you look at that and, certainly, on a GAAP basis, we had some additional costs on our Engle. So that is also coming through in SG&A from a GAAP basis.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to understand that, for the fourth quarter where you expect a stronger rate of growth, is it the incremental synergies coming through and I guess the absence of some of these expenses that leads to the stronger fourth quarter profit expecta
componenttext: Okay. And just to understand that, for the fourth quarter where you expect a stronger rate of growth, is it the incremental synergies coming through and I guess the absence of some of these expenses that leads to the stronger fourth quarter profit expectation?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is yes. So essentially, some of those expenses will wind down, and certainly, we'll have a full run rate on synergies as well.
componenttext: The answer is yes. So essentially, some of those expenses will wind down, and certainly, we'll have a full run rate on synergies as well.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a question related to the all other division, where you had a little bit of a larger operating loss there. Not a big surprise given some of the activity in the quarter. I guess I just want to understand, been asking this for several qu
componenttext: Okay. And then just a question related to the all other division, where you had a little bit of a larger operating loss there. Not a big surprise given some of the activity in the quarter. I guess I just want to understand, been asking this for several quarters now, but just to understand. You were hopefully moving back closer towards kind of breakeven profitability, some pushed out a bit. Is it just the expenses related to some of the new products that could continue into 4Q as well and keep that loss at a bit of a higher level?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, certainly, we continue to make very good progress on RJR Vapor. And that continues to move in the right direction. We're very pleased with that overall trajectory. But from a total all other standpoint, we've had some slightly higher spend a
componenttext: Yes. I think, certainly, we continue to make very good progress on RJR Vapor. And that continues to move in the right direction. We're very pleased with that overall trajectory. But from a total all other standpoint, we've had some slightly higher spend as we've rolled out Niconovum. We've had some slightly higher spend on our innovations. So some of those things are certainly coming through and offsetting. But yes, we would expect to have some continued investment.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Lavery with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debra, Susan, congratulations to you both. Just was wondering if you could give some color a little more on the regulatory side. You've talked about some of the higher spending levels. Obviously, there's some structural things that come with that, you've
componenttext: Debra, Susan, congratulations to you both. Just was wondering if you could give some color a little more on the regulatory side. You've talked about some of the higher spending levels. Obviously, there's some structural things that come with that, you've called out with just needing to have headcount for some compliance things. But can you just talk a bit about where you stand on any PMTA or modified risk applications, either for vapor or for Eclipse?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Michael, we'll talk more about this in November. We'll give you a bit more of a longer view on some of our strategies within RAI Innovations. But certainly, the deeming kind of news coming out in May and then really the 90 days to get anythi
componenttext: Yes. I think, Michael, we'll talk more about this in November. We'll give you a bit more of a longer view on some of our strategies within RAI Innovations. But certainly, the deeming kind of news coming out in May and then really the 90 days to get anything into the market certainly drove a lot of investment in this quarter. And -- but going forward, the PMTA costs are real, and so we'll have to be complying with that within the next couple of years. And we do have plans to ensure that we can sustain our leadership position in this area. It's a key part of the strategy, and we'll make the necessary investments. But I think we do feel well prepared for it. We've got a great pipeline of innovations that we think is very relevant for the future. And so like I said, we'll provide a lot more color on our kind of submissions and give you a little bit of flavor for what that process is. But there is a significant cost to it, certainly. But I think there's also a lot of benefit.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And were you able to commercialize the products that you had wanted to ahead of the August 8 deadline that presumably you might distribute more broadly at a later date?
componenttext: And were you able to commercialize the products that you had wanted to ahead of the August 8 deadline that presumably you might distribute more broadly at a later date?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. And of course, you're seeing the first one of those. I talked really briefly about VUSE VIBE. But we're very excited to be expanding that even further already this year. So that will be going out into the market starting in -- it's alread
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. And of course, you're seeing the first one of those. I talked really briefly about VUSE VIBE. But we're very excited to be expanding that even further already this year. So that will be going out into the market starting in -- it's already in the market a little bit, but as far as really getting into really broad distribution, in November.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just looking further ahead. I know you said you'll elaborate more, but maybe just give us some glimpse of how you're thinking about heat-not-burn. Obviously, Altria hasn't even gotten approval or even applied yet for its IQOS platform. But if and
componenttext: And then just looking further ahead. I know you said you'll elaborate more, but maybe just give us some glimpse of how you're thinking about heat-not-burn. Obviously, Altria hasn't even gotten approval or even applied yet for its IQOS platform. But if and when that comes, how are you thinking about your approach, either with the current Eclipse product or a next generation of it? And what would you be doing to position yourself for a potentially different competitive landscape?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, I mean, we've -- and we've talked about this. We've got decades of experience in heat-not-burn, and we've learned a lot and we continue to learn more about that particular technology. And I am going to defer a little bit to say we'll talk mo
componenttext: Yes. Michael, I mean, we've -- and we've talked about this. We've got decades of experience in heat-not-burn, and we've learned a lot and we continue to learn more about that particular technology. And I am going to defer a little bit to say we'll talk more about that in November.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I, too, wish both Susan and Debra congratulations on your new roles. My first question, I was hoping you guys could provide a little further sauce on the state of the tobacco consumer because it actually seems there could be some softening, given risi
componenttext: And I, too, wish both Susan and Debra congratulations on your new roles. My first question, I was hoping you guys could provide a little further sauce on the state of the tobacco consumer because it actually seems there could be some softening, given rising gas prices and then some uncertainty given higher taxes and rising health care costs. So curious if you would agree with that characterization. And then how this may be limiting up-trading or the privatization trend that we've been seeing for so long.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Bonnie, I do think your characterization as far as -- what I would say is we see it returning a little more to normal. That being said, it's still a very favorable macroeconomic environment. It's just we're lapping now. I mean, it's been more than 18
componenttext: Yes. Bonnie, I do think your characterization as far as -- what I would say is we see it returning a little more to normal. That being said, it's still a very favorable macroeconomic environment. It's just we're lapping now. I mean, it's been more than 18 months that we've seen very, very favorable and even improving trends, I would say. And now what I think you have is a little more stagnating trends. But they're still, compared to historical, I mean, to be down on the year. What we're projecting, 2.5%, is still very good relative to that historical norm of down 2% to 4%. We haven't really seen a change, I would say, in premium. And our premium growth, in particular, has been very strong. And so we're still seeing very strong trends on Newport, on Natural American Spirit. So I think within the combustible portfolio, we're still seeing strong trends at the premium end. But we are -- certainly, you are seeing a little more activity in non-big 3. You are seeing a little bit of activity, certainly, in some of the cheaper forms of tobacco again as well. So -- but I think for relevant brands, relevant premium brands, we're still seeing very strong growth there. So we still feel very pleased with the state of the consumer. But I think your characterization of it, it's returning a bit more back to the norms.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that actually brings me to my second question with some of your comments, more on Pall Mall because it does seem that, that brand has been facing an increased amount of pressure. So maybe you could drill down a little further on that. And I gues
componenttext: Okay. And that actually brings me to my second question with some of your comments, more on Pall Mall because it does seem that, that brand has been facing an increased amount of pressure. So maybe you could drill down a little further on that. And I guess I'm getting the sense that, as you mentioned too, that the deep discount category has been picking up. So while premium might be staying quite strong, you're also seeing the bottom end increasing, I think. And is that possibly placing more pressure on Pall Mall? Or are you also facing pressure on Pall Mall from some of the other second-tier brands?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- so Pall Mall, we've talked about our portfolio strategy of really balancing the top line and bottom line there. I will say, for our portfolio currently, we are leaning a bit more toward the -- increasing the profit side of it because we ar
componenttext: Yes, I think -- so Pall Mall, we've talked about our portfolio strategy of really balancing the top line and bottom line there. I will say, for our portfolio currently, we are leaning a bit more toward the -- increasing the profit side of it because we are getting great growth at the premium end. And we -- so we're placing our investment and focuses at that premium end because we feel like that's the place to do it. That being said, we do have -- sequentially, we've had several quarters of being relatively flat. We're just -- it's in comparison to prior years where we are still seeing that pressure. But I think for now, we're very happy and very pleased with where our portfolio is at, and Pall Mall is playing its role.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then final quick question is on your core heat-not-burn product that you, I believe, tested in Japan. Do you have any update that you can provide us this morning on how that launched?
componenttext: Okay. And then final quick question is on your core heat-not-burn product that you, I believe, tested in Japan. Do you have any update that you can provide us this morning on how that launched?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I will say is we did complete our test of core in Japan. We were very pleased with the results, and we'll talk more in November about heat-not-burn.
componenttext: What I will say is we did complete our test of core in Japan. We were very pleased with the results, and we'll talk more in November about heat-not-burn.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Megan Cody with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Megan Cody with UBS.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get some more color on what cigarette industry pricing growth is running at if you strip out the mix impacts of industry premiumization. And how do you expect that change going forward?
componenttext: I was hoping to get some more color on what cigarette industry pricing growth is running at if you strip out the mix impacts of industry premiumization. And how do you expect that change going forward?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've seen over the past couple of years is sort of 5% to 7% for our business, and I think that's right where we sit today. As we said, on an adjusted -- sort of an adjustment basis here, if you strip out the contract manufacturing, we would've
componenttext: Well, what we've seen over the past couple of years is sort of 5% to 7% for our business, and I think that's right where we sit today. As we said, on an adjusted -- sort of an adjustment basis here, if you strip out the contract manufacturing, we would've been in that range. So 5% to 7% is sort of where it's been running, and that's been very positive for us.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's excluding the mix impact of premiumization?
componenttext: And that's excluding the mix impact of premiumization?

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. There are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to Mr. Bannon.
componenttext: Okay. There are no further questions at this time. I'll turn the call back over to Mr. Bannon.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This is Susan, everybody. I just wanted to take the opportunity as this will be my last earnings call as the CEO. I do look forward to seeing you all in New York. But I would like to comment on the headlines around the misses. I think it would
componenttext: Thank you. This is Susan, everybody. I just wanted to take the opportunity as this will be my last earnings call as the CEO. I do look forward to seeing you all in New York. But I would like to comment on the headlines around the misses. I think it would be relevant to bring to your attention that the midpoint of our guidance range has not changed since February when we gave guidance and that we are very, very pleased with our 15% to 18% growth, and we are confident that we will deliver that. We are the only company really growing premium market share. And I think it's important to look at this business on an annual basis and not get so worked up over these quarter-to-quarters. We are on our plan. We delivered double-digit last year, and we will do, as we said, 15% to 18% this year. And we are very excited about this portfolio and our commitment to returning value to our shareholders. So I thank you all very much. And I've enjoyed working with you, and I'll see you next month. Thank you.

headline: Reynolds American Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
